End-time signs are predicted (Matt 24:3, 30; Luke 21:11, 25). False christs show signs (Matt 24:24; 2 Thess 2:9).

keyPassages.greek: ταύτην ἐποίησεν ἀρχὴν τῶν σημείων ὁ Ἰησοῦς... καὶ ἐφανέρωσεν τὴν δόξαν αὐτοῦ
keyPassages.significance: The first of signs, manifesting His glory - signs as revelation of Christ's identity.

keyPassages.greek: ταῦτα δὲ γέγραπται ἵνα πιστεύ[σ]ητε ὅτι Ἰησοῦς ἐστιν ὁ χριστὸς ὁ υἱὸς τοῦ θεοῦ
keyPassages.significance: These are written so you may believe - signs recorded to produce faith.

keyPassages.greek: γενεὰ πονηρὰ καὶ μοιχαλὶς σημεῖον ἐπιζητεῖ
keyPassages.significance: An evil and adulterous generation seeks a sign - sign-seeking as unbelief.

entries.theologicalSignificance: Signs point beyond themselves to Christ and His mission. They are not ends in themselves but windows into divine reality. Faith should not require signs, yet signs are given to strengthen faith. The danger is seeking signs without seeing what they signify - missing the revelation while demanding more miracles. John's signs progressively reveal Jesus: authority over nature, sickness, death, culminating in His own resurrection. Signs authenticate messengers (apostolic signs - 2 Cor 12:12) but can be counterfeited (2 Thess 2:9). True faith penetrates beyond sign to significance.

relatedWords.relationship: Wonder, portent (often paired: signs and wonders)
Power, miracle - emphasizes power rather than revelatory function

entries.title: Power: The Divine Energy at Work
entries.summary: Δύναμις is power - the inherent ability to accomplish. It describes God's omnipotent power, Christ's miraculous power, the Spirit's enabling power, and the gospel's saving power. Divine power works in human weakness.
entries.classicalGreek: In classical Greek, δύναμις meant 'power, strength, ability' - the capacity to act or produce effects. It applied to physical, political, and military power. Aristotle distinguished δύναμις (potentiality) from ἐνέργεια (actuality). The term had both concrete and abstract applications.
entries.lxxBackground: The LXX uses δύναμις for various Hebrew words expressing God's power: גְּבוּרָה (geburah, 'might'), חַיִל (chayil, 'strength'). God's power created, delivers, and judges. 'Power' and 'glory' are frequently paired (Ps 63:2; 145:11). 'Lord of hosts' (צְבָאוֹת) becomes κύριος τῶν δυνάμεων - Lord of powers/armies.
entries.intertestamental: God's power in creation, history, and coming salvation remained central. Apocalyptic texts emphasized God's power to judge and transform. 'Powers' (δυνάμεις) could refer to angelic beings. God's power would be revealed decisively in the end times.
entries.ntUsage: God's power is unlimited (Matt 22:29; Rom 1:20). Christ performed δυνάμεις (miracles/mighty works - Matt 11:20-21). The Spirit provides power (Acts 1:8; Rom 15:13, 19). The gospel is God's power for salvation (Rom 1:16; 1 Cor 1:18). Power is perfected in weakness (2 Cor 12:9). Believers are kept by God's power (1 Pet 1:5). Christ is the power of God (1 Cor 1:24). Resurrection power is available to believers (Eph 1:19-20; Phil 3:10).

keyPassages.greek: λήμψεσθε δύναμιν ἐπελθόντος τοῦ ἁγίου πνεύματος ἐφ᾽ ὑμᾶς
keyPassages.significance: You will receive power when the Holy Spirit comes - Spirit as source of missional power.

keyPassages.greek: ἀρκεῖ σοι ἡ χάρις μου, ἡ γὰρ δύναμις ἐν ἀσθενείᾳ τελεῖται
keyPassages.significance: My grace is sufficient; power is perfected in weakness - divine power, human weakness.

keyPassages.greek: τὸ ὑπερβάλλον μέγεθος τῆς δυνάμεως αὐτοῦ... κατὰ τὴν ἐνέργειαν τοῦ κράτους τῆς ἰσχύος αὐτοῦ
keyPassages.significance: The surpassing greatness of His power - resurrection power available to believers.

entries.theologicalSignificance: Divine power (δύναμις) distinguishes true Christianity. The gospel is not philosophy but power - it actually transforms. The Spirit enables what law could only command. Paradoxically, this power works through weakness: the cross is God's power (1 Cor 1:18, 24), and human weakness displays divine strength (2 Cor 12:9-10). Believers are 'filled with power' (Col 1:11) but never possess it independently - it flows from abiding in Christ. Power-seeking apart from service corrupts; divine power always serves love's purposes.

entries.title: Authority: The Rightful Power to Act
entries.summary: Ἐξουσία is authority - the right or freedom to act, delegated power, jurisdiction. Christ received all authority, delegated authority to apostles, and His authority extends over disease, demons, death, and all creation.
entries.classicalGreek: In classical Greek, ἐξουσία (from ἔξεστι, 'it is permitted') meant 'freedom of action, right, authority.' It emphasized not raw power but legitimate power - the right to act, permission granted, authority possessed. It could denote political authority, personal liberty, or capability.
entries.lxxBackground: The LXX uses ἐξουσία for various terms relating to rule, authority, and domain. Daniel 7:14 gives the Son of Man 'authority' (ἐξουσία) and dominion. Human rulers exercise authority under God's sovereignty. All authority ultimately derives from God (Prov 8:15-16).
entries.intertestamental: Authority belonged to God, delegated to human and angelic rulers. Apocalyptic literature distinguished God's authority from illegitimate demonic usurpation. The coming kingdom would restore proper authority structures. Various 'authorities' (angelic powers) featured in cosmological speculation.
entries.ntUsage: Christ has all authority (Matt 28:18). He taught with authority (Matt 7:29), forgave with authority (Matt 9:6), and commanded spirits with authority (Mark 1:27). He gave authority to disciples (Matt 10:1; Luke 10:19). All authority comes from God (John 19:11; Rom 13:1-2). Believers have authority to become God's children (John 1:12). Powers and authorities were defeated (Col 2:15) but remain active (Eph 6:12). Christ will hand kingdom authority to the Father (1 Cor 15:24).

keyPassages.greek: ἐδόθη μοι πᾶσα ἐξουσία ἐν οὐρανῷ καὶ ἐπὶ γῆς
keyPassages.significance: All authority in heaven and on earth given to me - Christ's universal lordship.

keyPassages.greek: ἔδωκεν αὐτοῖς ἐξουσίαν τέκνα θεοῦ γενέσθαι
keyPassages.significance: He gave them authority to become children of God - the right of adoption.

keyPassages.greek: οὐ γὰρ ἔστιν ἐξουσία εἰ μὴ ὑπὸ θεοῦ
keyPassages.significance: There is no authority except from God - divine source of all authority.

entries.theologicalSignificance: Authority (ἐξουσία) differs from mere power (δύναμις): it is rightful power, legitimate rule. Christ's authority is absolute and delegated from the Father. His authority demonstrates His divine identity. All human and spiritual authorities are under Christ's authority. Believers exercise delegated authority in spiritual warfare and mission. Authority must be exercised in service, not domination (Mark 10:42-45). The spiritual 'authorities' (Eph 6:12) are defeated but active; believers resist them by Christ's authority. Ultimate authority will be exercised when Christ subjects all things to the Father.

relatedWords.relationship: Power, might - often paired with authority

entries.title: Testimony: The Witness That Establishes Truth
entries.summary: Μαρτυρία is testimony or witness - the attestation of truth. God, Christ, the Spirit, Scripture, and believers all bear witness. In John's writings especially, testimony language pervades: the Father testifies to the Son, and believers testify to the world.
entries.classicalGreek: In classical Greek, μαρτυρία meant 'testimony, witness, evidence' - especially in legal contexts. The μάρτυς (witness) gave μαρτυρία (testimony). Truth required witnesses; testimony established facts. The concept was fundamentally forensic.
entries.lxxBackground: The LXX uses μαρτυρία for עֵדוּת (edut, 'testimony'). Two or three witnesses established truth (Deut 19:15). The covenant tablets were 'testimony' (Ex 25:16). False witness was forbidden (Ex 20:16). God Himself is witness (Gen 31:50; Jer 29:23).
entries.intertestamental: Legal witness procedures remained important. God's witness was ultimate. Martyrdom (dying for one's witness) began developing its specialized meaning. The righteous were witnesses to truth even unto death.
entries.ntUsage: John's Gospel emphasizes testimony: John the Baptist testified (John 1:7, 19, 32); Jesus testified (John 3:11, 32); the Father testified (John 5:37; 8:18); the works testified (John 5:36; 10:25); Scripture testified (John 5:39); the Spirit testified (John 15:26; 1 John 5:6-8). Believers are witnesses (Acts 1:8; 1 John 1:2). The 'testimony of Jesus' is central (Rev 1:2, 9; 12:17; 19:10). Martyrdom is the ultimate witness (Rev 6:9; 12:11).

keyPassages.greek: τὰ ἔργα... μαρτυρεῖ περὶ ἐμοῦ... καὶ ὁ πέμψας με πατὴρ ἐκεῖνος μεμαρτύρηκεν περὶ ἐμοῦ
keyPassages.significance: The works and the Father testify about me - multiple divine witnesses to Christ.

keyPassages.greek: ἡ μαρτυρία τοῦ θεοῦ μείζων ἐστίν... αὕτη ἐστὶν ἡ μαρτυρία, ὅτι ζωὴν αἰώνιον ἔδωκεν ἡμῖν ὁ θεός
keyPassages.significance: God's testimony is greater - His testimony is that He gave us eternal life.

keyPassages.greek: αὐτοὶ ἐνίκησαν αὐτὸν διὰ τὸ αἷμα τοῦ ἀρνίου καὶ διὰ τὸν λόγον τῆς μαρτυρίας αὐτῶν
keyPassages.significance: They conquered by the blood of the Lamb and the word of their testimony.

entries.theologicalSignificance: Truth is established through witness. The Trinity testifies: Father to Son, Spirit to both. Scripture testifies to Christ. Believers receive and pass on testimony. Faithful witness may cost life - hence μάρτυς becomes 'martyr.' The testimony focuses on Christ: who He is, what He has done. Rejecting testimony brings judgment (John 3:32-33). Faithful witness is part of spiritual warfare (Rev 12:11). The church's mission is witness (Acts 1:8). This is not mere opinion-sharing but solemn attestation to divine truth.

entries.title: World: Creation Under Judgment and Redemption
entries.summary: Κόσμος has multiple meanings: the created order, humanity, or the world-system opposed to God. God loved the world and sent His Son to save it, yet the world lies in the evil one. Believers are in the world but not of it.
entries.classicalGreek: In classical Greek, κόσμος meant 'order, arrangement, ornament' - hence 'cosmetics.' Philosophers applied it to the ordered universe (world). The term emphasizes ordered beauty - the world as structured, harmonious whole. It could also mean 'adornment.'
entries.lxxBackground: The LXX uses κόσμος occasionally for 'ornament' (Ex 33:5-6; Isa 49:18) and for the ordered world (Gen 2:1; Deut 4:19 - 'host of heaven'). However, Hebrew thought typically spoke of 'heaven and earth' rather than κόσμος. The term gains theological significance primarily in later Judaism and the NT.
entries.intertestamental: Greek philosophical concepts increasingly influenced Jewish thought. Wisdom literature personified Wisdom present at creation (Wisdom 9:9). 'This world' and 'the world to come' became standard eschatological categories. The world was God's creation but corrupted by evil.
entries.ntUsage: Κόσμος means: (1) the created universe (John 1:10a; Acts 17:24); (2) humanity (John 3:16; Rom 3:19); (3) the world-system opposed to God (John 15:18-19; 1 John 2:15-17; 5:19). God made the world (John 1:10), loves it (3:16), sent Christ to save it (3:17; 1 John 4:14). Yet the world doesn't know God (John 1:10; 1 Cor 1:21), hates believers (John 15:18), and lies in the evil one (1 John 5:19). Believers must not love the world (1 John 2:15-17). Christ has overcome the world (John 16:33).

keyPassages.greek: οὕτως γὰρ ἠγάπησεν ὁ θεὸς τὸν κόσμον, ὥστε τὸν υἱὸν τὸν μονογενῆ ἔδωκεν
keyPassages.significance: God so loved the world - the extent of divine redemptive love.

keyPassages.greek: μὴ ἀγαπᾶτε τὸν κόσμον μηδὲ τὰ ἐν τῷ κόσμῳ... ὅτι πᾶν τὸ ἐν τῷ κόσμῳ... οὐκ ἔστιν ἐκ τοῦ πατρός
keyPassages.significance: Do not love the world - the world-system as opposed to the Father.

keyPassages.greek: οὐκ εἰσὶν ἐκ τοῦ κόσμου καθὼς ἐγὼ οὐκ εἰμὶ ἐκ τοῦ κόσμου
keyPassages.significance: Not of the world, even as I am not - in the world but not of it.

entries.theologicalSignificance: The semantic range of κόσμος requires careful interpretation. God loves the world (humanity) and sent Christ to save it - this is not universalism but the scope of the offer. Yet believers must not 'love the world' (the anti-God system of values, priorities, and powers). The world-system is passing away (1 John 2:17; 1 Cor 7:31). Christ has overcome it (John 16:33). Believers are sent into the world (John 17:18) without being of it. Mission requires engagement without absorption. The tension between loving people and rejecting worldliness defines Christian existence until Christ returns.

entries.title: God: The One True and Living God
entries.summary: Θεός is the fundamental term for God in the NT - the one true God of Israel, Father of Jesus Christ, and Creator of all. The NT both assumes and transforms Jewish monotheism through the revelation of Father, Son, and Spirit.
entries.classicalGreek: In classical Greek, θεός referred to any deity in the polytheistic pantheon - Zeus, Athena, Apollo, etc. The word could denote divine beings of various ranks. Greek philosophy moved toward more abstract conceptions: Plato's divine craftsman, Aristotle's unmoved mover. The term carried connotations of power, immortality, and superhuman qualities.
entries.lxxBackground: The LXX uses θεός primarily for אֱלֹהִים (Elohim) and אֵל (El). It translates YHWH as κύριος (Lord) rather than θεός. The OT insists on one God (Deut 6:4), Creator (Gen 1:1), covenant-keeper, holy and jealous. 'I am God and there is no other' (Isa 45:22). The living God contrasts with dead idols.
entries.intertestamental: Judaism maintained strict monotheism against Hellenistic polytheism. God was increasingly described through attributes and intermediaries (Wisdom, Word, angels) to preserve transcendence. Philo spoke of θεός as the supreme being known through Logos. Apocalyptic emphasized God's sovereignty and coming judgment.
entries.ntUsage: God is Father of Jesus Christ (Rom 15:6; 2 Cor 1:3). Jesus is called θεός (John 1:1, 18; 20:28; Rom 9:5; Titus 2:13; Heb 1:8). The Spirit is God (Acts 5:3-4). God is one (1 Cor 8:6; Jas 2:19) yet Father, Son, and Spirit. God is love (1 John 4:8, 16), light (1 John 1:5), Spirit (John 4:24), consuming fire (Heb 12:29). He is faithful (1 Cor 1:9), just (Rom 3:26), merciful (Eph 2:4), and sovereign (Rom 9:18-21).

keyPassages.greek: Ἐν ἀρχῇ ἦν ὁ λόγος, καὶ ὁ λόγος ἦν πρὸς τὸν θεόν, καὶ θεὸς ἦν ὁ λόγος
keyPassages.significance: The Word was with God and was God - divine identity of the Logos.

keyPassages.greek: ὁ θεὸς ἀγάπη ἐστίν
keyPassages.significance: God is love - essential divine nature revealed in Christ.

keyPassages.greek: πνεῦμα ὁ θεός, καὶ τοὺς προσκυνοῦντας αὐτὸν ἐν πνεύματι καὶ ἀληθείᾳ δεῖ προσκυνεῖν
keyPassages.significance: God is Spirit - divine nature transcends material limitations.

entries.theologicalSignificance: The NT transforms Jewish monotheism without abandoning it. The one God exists as Father, Son, and Spirit - not three gods but one divine being in three persons. Jesus shares the divine name, receives worship, and exercises divine prerogatives. Yet 'the Father is greater' (John 14:28) in terms of order, not nature. God is knowable through Christ (John 1:18; 14:9) yet remains transcendent. Christian theology is fundamentally about θεός - who God is and how He has acted in Christ for salvation.

entries.title: Angel: Messengers of the Divine Council
entries.summary: Ἄγγελος means 'messenger' - either human or heavenly. Angels are spiritual beings who serve God, deliver messages, execute judgment, and minister to believers. Christ is superior to all angels, and believers will judge them.
entries.classicalGreek: In classical Greek, ἄγγελος simply meant 'messenger' or 'envoy' - one sent to deliver a message or perform a task. It applied to human messengers without supernatural connotations. The word comes from ἀγγέλλω ('to announce').
entries.lxxBackground: The LXX uses ἄγγελος for מַלְאָךְ (malak) - messenger, angel. The 'angel of the LORD' appears throughout the OT as a special divine messenger, sometimes identified with YHWH Himself (Gen 16:7-13; Ex 3:2-6). Angels form God's heavenly council (Job 1-2; Ps 89:7), worship Him (Ps 103:20), and execute His will.
entries.intertestamental: Angelology expanded greatly. Angels received names (Michael, Gabriel, Raphael, Uriel), ranks, and specific functions. 1 Enoch describes elaborate angelic hierarchies. Angels mediated the law (Jub. 1:27-29). Qumran expected angelic warfare. Speculation about angels sometimes bordered on angel worship.
entries.ntUsage: Angels announced Christ's birth (Luke 1-2), ministered to Him (Matt 4:11; Luke 22:43), proclaimed His resurrection (Matt 28:2-7), and will accompany His return (Matt 25:31; 2 Thess 1:7). Angels minister to believers (Heb 1:14), observe the church (1 Cor 4:9; 11:10), and rejoice over repentance (Luke 15:10). Christ is superior to angels (Heb 1:4-14). Angel worship is forbidden (Col 2:18; Rev 19:10; 22:8-9). Believers will judge angels (1 Cor 6:3).

keyPassages.greek: οὐχὶ πάντες εἰσὶν λειτουργικὰ πνεύματα εἰς διακονίαν ἀποστελλόμενα διὰ τοὺς μέλλοντας κληρονομεῖν σωτηρίαν
keyPassages.significance: Ministering spirits sent to serve those inheriting salvation - angelic ministry to believers.

keyPassages.greek: τοσούτῳ κρείττων γενόμενος τῶν ἀγγέλων ὅσῳ διαφορώτερον παρ᾽ αὐτοὺς κεκληρονόμηκεν ὄνομα
keyPassages.significance: Christ is superior to angels - the Son's supremacy over all created beings.

keyPassages.greek: ἐν τῇ ἀποκαλύψει τοῦ κυρίου Ἰησοῦ ἀπ᾽ οὐρανοῦ μετ᾽ ἀγγέλων δυνάμεως αὐτοῦ
keyPassages.significance: The Lord Jesus revealed from heaven with His mighty angels - eschatological role.

entries.theologicalSignificance: Angels are real spiritual beings, not myths or metaphors. They serve God and His people but are never to be worshiped. The emphasis on Christ's superiority to angels (Hebrews 1-2) counters any tendency to elevate angels above their proper place. Angels are created, Christ is Creator. Angels worship the Son (Heb 1:6). The 'angel of the LORD' in the OT may be pre-incarnate appearances of Christ. Believers have angelic protection (Matt 18:10) but must not seek angelic revelation apart from Christ (Col 2:18).

entries.title: Satan: The Adversary and Accuser
entries.summary: Σατανᾶς (from Hebrew שָׂטָן, 'adversary') is the personal name of the chief enemy of God and His people. Also called the devil (διάβολος), he tempts, accuses, deceives, and opposes God's purposes - but is defeated through Christ's cross and resurrection.
entries.classicalGreek: The term σατανᾶς does not occur in classical Greek. It is a transliteration of the Hebrew שָׂטָן (satan), meaning 'adversary' or 'accuser.' Greek culture had no direct equivalent, though δαίμων (demon) could denote malevolent spiritual beings.
entries.lxxBackground: The LXX sometimes transliterates שָׂטָן as σατάν or translates it as διάβολος ('slanderer, accuser'). In Job 1-2, the satan appears as a prosecuting attorney in God's court. In 1 Chronicles 21:1, Satan incites David. Zechariah 3:1-2 shows Satan accusing Joshua the high priest. The OT presents a developing portrait of a personal evil being.
entries.intertestamental: Satan's role expanded significantly. He became identified with the serpent of Genesis 3 (Wisdom 2:24). Elaborate demonologies developed, with Satan ruling fallen angels. He was called Belial, Mastema, and other names. Apocalyptic literature depicted cosmic warfare between God and Satan.
entries.ntUsage: Satan tempted Jesus (Matt 4:1-11), enters Judas (Luke 22:3; John 13:27), blinds unbelievers (2 Cor 4:4), prowls seeking to devour (1 Pet 5:8), and masquerades as light (2 Cor 11:14). He was defeated at the cross (John 12:31; Col 2:15; Heb 2:14) and will be finally destroyed (Rev 20:10). Believers resist him (Jas 4:7; 1 Pet 5:9) through Christ's power. He is called 'ruler of this world' (John 12:31), 'god of this age' (2 Cor 4:4), and 'prince of the power of the air' (Eph 2:2).

keyPassages.greek: ὁ ἀντίδικος ὑμῶν διάβολος ὡς λέων ὠρυόμενος περιπατεῖ ζητῶν τινα καταπιεῖν
keyPassages.significance: Your adversary the devil prowls like a roaring lion - Satan's predatory nature.

keyPassages.greek: ἵνα διὰ τοῦ θανάτου καταργήσῃ τὸν τὸ κράτος ἔχοντα τοῦ θανάτου, τοῦτ᾽ ἔστιν τὸν διάβολον
keyPassages.significance: Through death He destroyed the one holding the power of death - Satan's defeat.

keyPassages.greek: ὁ δράκων ὁ μέγας, ὁ ὄφις ὁ ἀρχαῖος, ὁ καλούμενος Διάβολος καὶ ὁ Σατανᾶς, ὁ πλανῶν τὴν οἰκουμένην ὅλην
keyPassages.significance: The ancient serpent, called the devil and Satan, deceiver of the whole world.

entries.theologicalSignificance: Satan is a real personal being, not merely a symbol of evil. He is powerful but not omnipotent, active but not sovereign. His defeat is accomplished (cross) and will be consummated (return). Believers must neither ignore him nor fear him excessively. Spiritual warfare is real (Eph 6:10-18) but victory is assured in Christ. Satan's primary weapons are deception (lies), accusation (guilt), and temptation (sin). Christ has bound the strong man (Matt 12:29) and given believers authority over all enemy power (Luke 10:19).

entries.title: Wrath: The Holy Response to Sin
entries.summary: Ὀργή is God's wrath - His holy, settled opposition to sin. Unlike human anger, divine wrath is not capricious but righteous, not vindictive but just. It is revealed against all ungodliness but averted through Christ's propitiation.
entries.classicalGreek: In classical Greek, ὀργή meant 'anger, wrath, passion' - an emotional response to perceived wrong. It was distinguished from θυμός (sudden outburst) as more settled, deliberate anger. Philosophers debated whether anger could ever be virtuous.
entries.lxxBackground: The LXX uses ὀργή for several Hebrew words, especially אַף (aph, 'nostril, anger') and חֵמָה (chemah, 'heat, wrath'). God's wrath burns against idolatry (Deut 29:20), injustice (Amos 2:6-16), and covenant-breaking (2 Kings 22:13). Yet God is 'slow to anger' (Ex 34:6) and His wrath is temporary while His mercy endures (Ps 30:5).
entries.intertestamental: The 'day of wrath' became a prominent eschatological theme (Zeph 1:15). Divine wrath was understood as the necessary response of holy God to sin. Some texts emphasized present wrath against sinners; others focused on future judgment. Wrath was not arbitrary but connected to covenant violation.
entries.ntUsage: God's wrath is revealed against all ungodliness (Rom 1:18). It abides on unbelievers (John 3:36). Jesus saves from coming wrath (1 Thess 1:10; 5:9). The 'day of wrath' approaches (Rom 2:5). Wrath is stored up for the impenitent (Rom 2:5). Christ bore God's wrath as propitiation (Rom 3:25). Believers are not destined for wrath (1 Thess 5:9). Human wrath is generally condemned (Jas 1:20; Eph 4:31), though righteous anger exists (Mark 3:5; Eph 4:26).

keyPassages.greek: Ἀποκαλύπτεται γὰρ ὀργὴ θεοῦ ἀπ᾽ οὐρανοῦ ἐπὶ πᾶσαν ἀσέβειαν καὶ ἀδικίαν ἀνθρώπων
keyPassages.significance: God's wrath is revealed from heaven against all ungodliness - present reality.

keyPassages.greek: Ἰησοῦν τὸν ῥυόμενον ἡμᾶς ἐκ τῆς ὀργῆς τῆς ἐρχομένης
keyPassages.significance: Jesus who delivers us from the coming wrath - eschatological salvation.

keyPassages.greek: ὁ πιστεύων εἰς τὸν υἱὸν ἔχει ζωὴν αἰώνιον· ὁ δὲ ἀπειθῶν τῷ υἱῷ οὐκ ὄψεται ζωήν, ἀλλ᾽ ἡ ὀργὴ τοῦ θεοῦ μένει ἐπ᾽ αὐτόν
keyPassages.significance: Whoever does not obey the Son - God's wrath remains on them.

entries.theologicalSignificance: Divine wrath is not divine spite. It is the holy response of a righteous God to sin. Without wrath, God would be morally indifferent. Wrath is the 'strange work' of God (Isa 28:21) - necessary but not His delight. The cross reveals both wrath and love: God's wrath against sin was poured out on Christ so that His love might embrace sinners. Those in Christ are saved from wrath (Rom 5:9). Those outside Christ remain under wrath. The gospel is urgent because wrath is real.

relatedWords.relationship: To be angry, provoke to anger

entries.title: Mercy: God's Compassionate Covenant Love
entries.summary: Ἔλεος is mercy - God's compassionate response to human misery and need. It reflects the Hebrew חֶסֶד (covenant love) and רַחֲמִים (tender compassion). God is rich in mercy, and His mercies are new every morning.
entries.classicalGreek: In classical Greek, ἔλεος meant 'pity, compassion, mercy' - the emotion aroused by undeserved suffering. It was considered a virtue by some philosophers (Aristotle) but weakness by others (Stoics). The word implied response to another's distress.
entries.lxxBackground: The LXX uses ἔλεος primarily for חֶסֶד (chesed, 'steadfast love, covenant loyalty') and רַחֲמִים (rachamim, 'tender mercies'). God's חֶסֶד is His covenant faithfulness and loyal love to His people (Ex 34:6; Ps 136). His רַחֲמִים are His tender, motherly compassion (Isa 49:15). 'His mercy endures forever' (Ps 136 refrain).
entries.intertestamental: Mercy remained central to Jewish understanding of God. The synagogue liturgy emphasized divine mercy. Sirach 2:18: 'Fall into the hands of the Lord, not into human hands, for as His majesty is, so is His mercy.' Mercy was hoped for at judgment.
entries.ntUsage: God is 'rich in mercy' (Eph 2:4) and 'Father of mercies' (2 Cor 1:3). Salvation is 'according to His mercy' (Titus 3:5; 1 Pet 1:3). Jesus showed mercy to the sick and sinful (Matt 9:27; 15:22; 17:15; Luke 17:13). Mercy triumphs over judgment (Jas 2:13). The merciful obtain mercy (Matt 5:7). Paul received mercy as chief of sinners (1 Tim 1:13-16). Gentiles received mercy to provoke Israel (Rom 11:30-32). 'His mercies are new every morning' (Lam 3:22-23, echoed in NT).

keyPassages.greek: ὁ δὲ θεὸς πλούσιος ὢν ἐν ἐλέει, διὰ τὴν πολλὴν ἀγάπην αὐτοῦ... συνεζωοποίησεν τῷ Χριστῷ
keyPassages.significance: God, being rich in mercy - mercy as the wellspring of salvation.

keyPassages.greek: οὐκ ἐξ ἔργων τῶν ἐν δικαιοσύνῃ ἃ ἐποιήσαμεν ἡμεῖς ἀλλὰ κατὰ τὸ αὐτοῦ ἔλεος ἔσωσεν ἡμᾶς
keyPassages.significance: Not by works but according to His mercy He saved us - mercy as salvation's basis.

keyPassages.greek: κατακαυχᾶται ἔλεος κρίσεως
keyPassages.significance: Mercy triumphs over judgment - the primacy of mercy.

entries.theologicalSignificance: Mercy is not mere emotion but divine action. God's mercy moves Him to save the undeserving. It is rooted in His covenant character - He is faithful to His promises even when His people are faithless. Mercy and grace are related but distinct: grace gives the undeserving good; mercy withholds from the guilty deserved punishment. Both meet in Christ. Receiving mercy transforms: 'Blessed are the merciful, for they shall receive mercy' (Matt 5:7). The church is a community of the mercied who show mercy.

entries.title: Wisdom: Divine Understanding Revealed in Christ
entries.summary: Σοφία is wisdom - the ability to understand and apply truth rightly. God's wisdom, hidden from the world, is revealed in Christ crucified. The cross is God's wisdom that shames worldly wisdom. Christ Himself is wisdom from God.
entries.classicalGreek: In classical Greek, σοφία meant 'skill, cleverness, wisdom' - originally practical skill (craftsmen), then intellectual wisdom (philosophers). Philosophy literally meant 'love of wisdom.' Greek sages sought wisdom through reason and contemplation. Wisdom was humanity's highest achievement.
entries.lxxBackground: The LXX uses σοφία for חָכְמָה (chokmah) - wisdom in practical living, understanding of God's ways, and skill in any domain. Wisdom is personified in Proverbs 8 as present at creation, calling humanity. 'The fear of the LORD is the beginning of wisdom' (Prov 9:10). Wisdom literature (Proverbs, Ecclesiastes, Job) explores wisdom's nature and limits.
entries.intertestamental: Wisdom speculation flourished. Sirach and Wisdom of Solomon personify Wisdom extensively, sometimes identifying her with Torah. Wisdom was pre-existent, participated in creation, and came to dwell with Israel. This provided background for NT Christology. Hellenistic Judaism (Philo) connected Wisdom with Logos.
entries.ntUsage: Christ is 'the wisdom of God' (1 Cor 1:24, 30). The cross is God's wisdom (1 Cor 1:18-25; 2:6-8). God's manifold wisdom is displayed through the church (Eph 3:10). Christ contains 'all treasures of wisdom' (Col 2:3). James distinguishes earthly wisdom from wisdom 'from above' (Jas 3:13-18). Believers should ask God for wisdom (Jas 1:5). The Spirit gives words of wisdom (1 Cor 12:8). Wisdom is needed for godly living (Col 1:9; 4:5).

keyPassages.greek: ἡμεῖς δὲ κηρύσσομεν Χριστὸν ἐσταυρωμένον... Χριστὸν θεοῦ δύναμιν καὶ θεοῦ σοφίαν
keyPassages.significance: We preach Christ crucified - God's power and God's wisdom.

keyPassages.greek: ὃς ἐγενήθη σοφία ἡμῖν ἀπὸ θεοῦ
keyPassages.significance: Christ became to us wisdom from God - Christ as embodied wisdom.

keyPassages.greek: ἡ δὲ ἄνωθεν σοφία πρῶτον μὲν ἁγνή ἐστιν, ἔπειτα εἰρηνική, ἐπιεικής
keyPassages.significance: Wisdom from above is first pure, then peaceable, gentle - wisdom's character.

entries.theologicalSignificance: The cross inverts all human values including wisdom. What the world considers foolish - a crucified Messiah - is God's wisdom. This wisdom was hidden but is now revealed (1 Cor 2:7). Believers don't need worldly credentials to have true wisdom; they have Christ. Yet wisdom must be applied - James emphasizes practical wisdom that produces righteous living. The Spirit enables wisdom (1 Cor 2:10-13). Christians should be 'wise as serpents' (Matt 10:16), walking wisely (Eph 5:15-16), and speaking with wisdom (Col 4:5-6).

entries.title: Light: The Divine Reality That Exposes and Saves
entries.summary: Φῶς is light - both physical illumination and spiritual revelation. God is light; Christ is the light of the world; believers are children of light. Light exposes darkness, reveals truth, and enables sight. Walking in light is walking in fellowship with God.
entries.classicalGreek: In classical Greek, φῶς meant 'light' - both literal (daylight, fire) and metaphorical (life, truth, knowledge). Light was associated with divinity, truth, and goodness. Darkness represented ignorance, evil, and death. Greek philosophy often used light/darkness imagery for knowledge/ignorance.
entries.lxxBackground: The LXX uses φῶς for אוֹר (or). God's first creative word was 'Let there be light' (Gen 1:3). God Himself is light (Ps 27:1; Isa 60:19-20). His word is a lamp (Ps 119:105). Light symbolizes salvation, joy, and divine favor. The Servant will be 'a light for the nations' (Isa 42:6; 49:6).
entries.intertestamental: Light/darkness dualism intensified, especially at Qumran where the 'sons of light' battled 'sons of darkness.' Light represented God's realm; darkness, Satan's. The coming age would be characterized by light. Messianic expectation included the dawn of light.
entries.ntUsage: 'God is light' (1 John 1:5). Christ is 'the light of the world' (John 8:12; 9:5) and 'the true light' (John 1:9). Believers are 'children of light' (Eph 5:8; 1 Thess 5:5) and 'light of the world' (Matt 5:14). Light exposes evil (John 3:19-21; Eph 5:13). Christians should walk in light (1 John 1:7), wear armor of light (Rom 13:12), and shine as lights (Phil 2:15). The gospel brings light (2 Cor 4:4-6). Heaven needs no sun - God is its light (Rev 21:23; 22:5).

keyPassages.greek: Ἐγώ εἰμι τὸ φῶς τοῦ κόσμου· ὁ ἀκολουθῶν ἐμοὶ οὐ μὴ περιπατήσῃ ἐν τῇ σκοτίᾳ
keyPassages.significance: I am the light of the world - Christ's fundamental self-revelation.

keyPassages.greek: ὁ θεὸς φῶς ἐστιν καὶ σκοτία ἐν αὐτῷ οὐκ ἔστιν οὐδεμία
keyPassages.significance: God is light, and in Him is no darkness at all - absolute divine purity.

keyPassages.greek: Ὑμεῖς ἐστε τὸ φῶς τοῦ κόσμου
keyPassages.significance: You are the light of the world - believers' mission to illuminate.

entries.theologicalSignificance: Light represents God's nature - holiness, truth, and life. Darkness represents sin, error, and death. There is no neutral ground. To come to Christ is to come from darkness to light (Acts 26:18; 1 Pet 2:9). Walking in light means living in truth and fellowship with God (1 John 1:7). Light exposes - people love darkness because their deeds are evil (John 3:19). Believers reflect Christ's light to the world. The consummation will be endless light in God's presence.

entries.title: Darkness: The Realm of Sin and Ignorance
entries.summary: Σκότος is darkness - the realm opposed to God's light. It represents sin, ignorance, Satan's domain, and spiritual death. Christ came to rescue people from darkness. Believers were once darkness but are now light in the Lord.
entries.classicalGreek: In classical Greek, σκότος meant 'darkness, gloom' - absence of light. Metaphorically it represented ignorance, obscurity, and the realm of death. Darkness was associated with fear, the underworld, and the unknown. The contrast with light was fundamental to Greek thought.
entries.lxxBackground: The LXX uses σκότος for חֹשֶׁךְ (choshek). Darkness existed before creation (Gen 1:2). The plague of darkness struck Egypt (Ex 10:21-23). Darkness represents judgment (Amos 5:18-20), death (Job 10:21-22), and spiritual blindness (Isa 9:2). Yet God 'forms light and creates darkness' (Isa 45:7) - both are under His sovereignty.
entries.intertestamental: Dualistic thinking intensified. At Qumran, the 'sons of light' opposed the 'sons of darkness.' The present age was characterized by darkness; the coming age by light. Satan was 'prince of darkness.' This dualism was ethical and eschatological, not metaphysical - God remained sovereign over darkness.
entries.ntUsage: The people in darkness have seen a great light (Matt 4:16). Darkness cannot overcome the light (John 1:5). Evil deeds love darkness (John 3:19). Believers are transferred from darkness to light (Col 1:13; 1 Pet 2:9). We are not of darkness (1 Thess 5:4-5). Don't participate in works of darkness (Eph 5:11). Our struggle is against 'cosmic powers of this darkness' (Eph 6:12). Outer darkness awaits the condemned (Matt 8:12; 22:13; 25:30). Hell is 'blackest darkness' (2 Pet 2:17; Jude 13).

keyPassages.greek: ὃς ἐρρύσατο ἡμᾶς ἐκ τῆς ἐξουσίας τοῦ σκότους καὶ μετέστησεν εἰς τὴν βασιλείαν τοῦ υἱοῦ
keyPassages.significance: He rescued us from the domain of darkness - salvation as transfer of realms.

keyPassages.greek: ἦτε γάρ ποτε σκότος, νῦν δὲ φῶς ἐν κυρίῳ
keyPassages.significance: You were once darkness, but now you are light - transformation, not mere location change.

keyPassages.greek: ἠγάπησαν οἱ ἄνθρωποι μᾶλλον τὸ σκότος ἢ τὸ φῶς· ἦν γὰρ αὐτῶν πονηρὰ τὰ ἔργα
keyPassages.significance: People loved darkness rather than light because their deeds were evil.

entries.theologicalSignificance: Darkness is not merely absence of light but active opposition to it. People don't merely lack truth; they suppress it (Rom 1:18). Darkness describes both the realm of evil and the character of those in it - 'you were darkness' (Eph 5:8). Conversion is a transfer of citizenship from darkness to light. The 'outer darkness' of judgment is the final state of those who reject the light. Believers must not merely avoid darkness but expose it (Eph 5:11). The cross occurred in darkness (Luke 23:44) as Christ bore humanity's darkness.

entries.title: Elder: The Mature Leader of God's People
entries.summary: Πρεσβύτερος means 'elder' - originally an older, respected person, then a designated leader. In the church, elders (also called overseers) shepherd God's flock, teach, and exercise pastoral oversight. They must meet specific qualifications and are accountable to Christ, the Chief Shepherd.
entries.classicalGreek: In classical Greek, πρεσβύτερος (comparative of πρέσβυς, 'old man') meant 'older' or 'elder.' It designated senior members of a community who naturally commanded respect and often held leadership roles. Age implied wisdom and authority.
entries.lxxBackground: The LXX uses πρεσβύτερος for זָקֵן (zaqen, 'elder'). Elders led Israel (Ex 3:16; 4:29), judged disputes (Deut 21:19; 22:15), and represented the people (1 Sam 8:4). The seventy elders assisted Moses (Num 11:16-25). Elders sat at city gates, administered justice, and preserved tradition.
entries.intertestamental: Synagogues were governed by elders. The Sanhedrin included elders. Elder governance was the standard pattern for Jewish communities. Elders were respected for their wisdom, experience, and knowledge of tradition. The term became a title more than an age designation.
entries.ntUsage: Churches had elders (Acts 14:23; 20:17; Titus 1:5). Elders must be qualified (1 Tim 3:1-7; Titus 1:5-9). They shepherd/oversee (Acts 20:28; 1 Pet 5:1-4), teach (1 Tim 5:17), pray for the sick (Jas 5:14), and lead (1 Tim 5:17; Heb 13:17). 'Elder' and 'overseer' (ἐπίσκοπος) are interchangeable (Acts 20:17, 28; Titus 1:5, 7). Elders should be honored, especially those who labor in preaching (1 Tim 5:17-19). Twenty-four elders surround God's throne (Rev 4:4, 10; 5:8).

keyPassages.greek: πρεσβυτέρους οὖν ἐν ὑμῖν παρακαλῶ... ποιμάνατε τὸ ἐν ὑμῖν ποίμνιον τοῦ θεοῦ
keyPassages.significance: I exhort the elders among you: shepherd God's flock - pastoral responsibility.

keyPassages.greek: τούτου χάριν ἀπέλιπόν σε ἐν Κρήτῃ, ἵνα... καταστήσῃς κατὰ πόλιν πρεσβυτέρους
keyPassages.significance: I left you in Crete to appoint elders in every town - church structure.

keyPassages.greek: προσέχετε ἑαυτοῖς καὶ παντὶ τῷ ποιμνίῳ, ἐν ᾧ ὑμᾶς τὸ πνεῦμα τὸ ἅγιον ἔθετο ἐπισκόπους
keyPassages.significance: The Holy Spirit made you overseers - Spirit-appointed, with shepherding duty.

entries.theologicalSignificance: Elder leadership is the NT pattern for church governance. Elders are Spirit-appointed (Acts 20:28) but publicly recognized (Acts 14:23; Titus 1:5). They must meet character and ability qualifications - leadership flows from life. The plurality of elders provides shared responsibility and accountability. Elders are under-shepherds serving the Chief Shepherd, Christ (1 Pet 5:4). They will give account for souls (Heb 13:17). The office requires both godly character and teaching ability. Elders lead by example, not domination (1 Pet 5:3).

relatedWords.relationship: Overseer, bishop - same office as elder

entries.title: Prophet: The Spokesperson of God
entries.summary: Προφήτης is a prophet - one who speaks forth God's word. OT prophets proclaimed God's message; NT prophets continued this ministry in the church. Christ is the ultimate Prophet. Prophecy must be tested, and all prophecy points to Christ.
entries.classicalGreek: In classical Greek, προφήτης (from πρό 'forth' + φημί 'speak') meant one who speaks for a god, an interpreter of divine will. It applied to those who proclaimed oracles at shrines like Delphi. The emphasis was on speaking forth rather than predicting the future.
entries.lxxBackground: The LXX uses προφήτης for נָבִיא (nabi) - one called to speak God's word. Moses was the paradigm prophet (Deut 18:15-18). Prophets like Elijah, Isaiah, Jeremiah, and Ezekiel confronted Israel with God's word, called for repentance, announced judgment, and proclaimed hope. 'Thus says the LORD' marked prophetic speech.
entries.intertestamental: Prophecy was believed to have ceased after Malachi until the messianic age. The hope remained: 'until a prophet should arise' (1 Macc 4:46; 14:41). John the Baptist was seen as the return of prophetic voice. Prophetic expectation was high at Jesus' time.
entries.ntUsage: Jesus was recognized as a prophet (Matt 21:11; Luke 7:16; John 4:19). He is the Prophet like Moses (Acts 3:22-23; 7:37). John the Baptist was a prophet (Matt 11:9). Prophets were foundational to the church (Eph 2:20; 4:11). Prophecy is a spiritual gift (1 Cor 12:10, 28; 14:1-5). Prophets must be tested (1 Cor 14:29; 1 Thess 5:20-21; 1 John 4:1). False prophets exist (Matt 7:15; 24:11, 24; 1 John 4:1). The testimony of Jesus is the spirit of prophecy (Rev 19:10).

keyPassages.greek: προφήτην ὑμῖν ἀναστήσει κύριος ὁ θεὸς ἐκ τῶν ἀδελφῶν ὑμῶν ὡς ἐμέ
keyPassages.significance: The Lord will raise up a prophet like me - Christ as the Prophet.

keyPassages.greek: ἐποικοδομηθέντες ἐπὶ τῷ θεμελίῳ τῶν ἀποστόλων καὶ προφητῶν
keyPassages.significance: Built on the foundation of apostles and prophets - foundational ministry.

keyPassages.greek: ὁ δὲ προφητεύων ἀνθρώποις λαλεῖ οἰκοδομὴν καὶ παράκλησιν καὶ παραμυθίαν
keyPassages.significance: The one who prophesies speaks to people for building up, encouragement, consolation.

entries.theologicalSignificance: Prophets speak God's word - both forth-telling (proclamation) and fore-telling (prediction). Christ is the ultimate Prophet - God's final Word (Heb 1:1-2). OT prophets pointed to Christ; NT prophets proclaim Him. The gift of prophecy continues but is subordinate to Scripture and must be tested. All claimed prophecy must align with apostolic teaching. The prophet's role is not to add new doctrine but to apply and illumine existing revelation. False prophecy is serious; true prophecy builds up the church.

entries.title: Heaven: God's Throne and Believers' Hope
entries.summary: Οὐρανός means heaven - the sky above, the realm of God's dwelling, and the final destination of believers. 'Heaven' often stands for God Himself. The kingdom of heaven is at hand; believers' citizenship is in heaven; Christ will return from heaven.
entries.classicalGreek: In classical Greek, οὐρανός meant the visible sky, the vault of heaven where the gods dwelt (Olympus). It was personified as the god Ouranos. Greek thought distinguished the earthly realm below from the heavenly realm above, the latter being more divine and eternal.
entries.lxxBackground: The LXX uses οὐρανός for שָׁמַיִם (shamayim, always plural in Hebrew). Heaven can mean: (1) the atmosphere/sky (Gen 1:8); (2) the stellar heavens (Gen 1:14-17); (3) God's dwelling place (1 Kings 8:30). 'Heaven and earth' denotes all creation. God is 'in heaven' yet 'heaven of heavens cannot contain Him' (1 Kings 8:27).
entries.intertestamental: Elaborate heavenly geography developed - multiple heavens (3, 7, or more), with God's throne in the highest. Paul was caught up to 'third heaven' (2 Cor 12:2). Heaven was the realm of angels, the destination of the righteous dead, and the source of eschatological salvation. The hope of 'entering heaven' solidified.
entries.ntUsage: The kingdom of heaven is near (Matt 3:2; 4:17). Our Father is 'in heaven' (Matt 6:9). Treasure should be stored in heaven (Matt 6:20). Names are written in heaven (Luke 10:20). Christ ascended to heaven (Acts 1:11) and will return from there (1 Thess 4:16). Believers' citizenship is in heaven (Phil 3:20), their inheritance kept there (1 Pet 1:4). New heaven and new earth await (2 Pet 3:13; Rev 21:1). Heaven is opened in visions (Acts 7:56; Rev 4:1; 19:11).

keyPassages.greek: Πάτερ ἡμῶν ὁ ἐν τοῖς οὐρανοῖς... ἐλθέτω ἡ βασιλεία σου· γενηθήτω τὸ θέλημά σου, ὡς ἐν οὐρανῷ καὶ ἐπὶ γῆς
keyPassages.significance: Our Father in heaven - Your kingdom come, on earth as in heaven.

keyPassages.greek: ἡμῶν γὰρ τὸ πολίτευμα ἐν οὐρανοῖς ὑπάρχει, ἐξ οὗ καὶ σωτῆρα ἀπεκδεχόμεθα
keyPassages.significance: Our citizenship is in heaven, from which we await a Savior.

keyPassages.greek: εἶδον οὐρανὸν καινὸν καὶ γῆν καινήν
keyPassages.significance: I saw a new heaven and a new earth - the consummated hope.

entries.theologicalSignificance: Heaven is both present reality and future hope. God's will is done perfectly there now; we pray for earth to match heaven. Christ is in heaven interceding; believers are seated there spiritually (Eph 2:6). Heaven is not disembodied existence but the realm of God's presence. The final state is not souls going to heaven but heaven coming to earth (Rev 21:2) - the new creation where God dwells with humanity. 'Going to heaven' is intermediate; resurrection in new creation is ultimate. Heaven represents the already of salvation; new heaven and earth the not yet.

entries.title: Father: The Revealed Name of God
entries.summary: Πατήρ is 'father' - used for human fathers, ancestors, and supremely for God. Jesus' distinctive revelation is that God is 'Abba, Father.' The Father sends the Son and Spirit; believers are adopted as children of the Father.
entries.classicalGreek: In classical Greek, πατήρ meant 'father' in the natural sense, extending to ancestors, founders, and originators. Zeus was called 'father of gods and men' - a title of authority and origin rather than intimate relationship. Philosophers spoke of the divine as 'father' of the cosmos.
entries.lxxBackground: The LXX uses πατήρ for אָב (ab). God is Israel's Father (Deut 32:6; Isa 63:16; 64:8; Mal 2:10) - by creation and covenant. Yet direct address to God as 'Father' is rare in the OT. The fatherhood emphasizes God's authority, care, and Israel's obligation as children.
entries.intertestamental: God as Father appears occasionally (Sirach 23:1, 4; Wisdom 14:3; 3 Macc 6:3). The concept remained primarily corporate - God as Father of Israel - rather than individual. No evidence exists for 'Abba' as direct address to God before Jesus.
entries.ntUsage: Jesus uniquely calls God 'Abba, Father' (Mark 14:36) and teaches disciples to pray 'Our Father' (Matt 6:9). The Father is revealed through the Son (Matt 11:27; John 14:9). The Father sends the Son (John 3:16; Gal 4:4) and the Spirit (John 14:26). Believers receive adoption as children (Rom 8:15; Gal 4:5-6) and cry 'Abba, Father.' God is 'Father of mercies' (2 Cor 1:3), 'Father of lights' (Jas 1:17), and 'Father of glory' (Eph 1:17). The Father's love is supreme (1 John 3:1).

keyPassages.greek: Πάτερ ἡμῶν ὁ ἐν τοῖς οὐρανοῖς, ἁγιασθήτω τὸ ὄνομά σου
keyPassages.significance: Our Father in heaven - the model prayer begins with intimate address.

keyPassages.greek: ἐλάβετε πνεῦμα υἱοθεσίας ἐν ᾧ κράζομεν· Αββα ὁ πατήρ
keyPassages.significance: You received the Spirit of adoption by whom we cry 'Abba, Father.'

keyPassages.greek: ὁ ἑωρακὼς ἐμὲ ἑώρακεν τὸν πατέρα
keyPassages.significance: Whoever has seen me has seen the Father - Christ reveals the Father.

entries.theologicalSignificance: Jesus' revelation of God as Father is revolutionary. The intimacy of 'Abba' (Aramaic for 'dear father') was unprecedented. This fatherhood is not generic but specifically 'the Father of our Lord Jesus Christ' (Eph 1:3). Through union with Christ, believers share His relationship - 'my Father and your Father' (John 20:17). The Father initiates salvation (elects, sends, draws), the Son accomplishes it, the Spirit applies it. Divine fatherhood grounds human fatherhood (Eph 3:14-15). God's fatherhood combines tender care with holy authority.

entries.title: Body: The Whole Person in Physical Expression
entries.summary: Σῶμα is body - the physical aspect of human existence. Unlike Greek dualism that despised the body, biblical thought values embodiment. Christ took a body, believers are the body of Christ, and resurrection is bodily.
entries.classicalGreek: In classical Greek, σῶμα meant 'body' - originally a corpse, then the living body. Platonic thought viewed the body as the prison of the soul (σῶμα-σῆμα, 'body-tomb'). The goal was liberation from bodily existence. Greek dualism sharply divided body (material, evil) from soul (spiritual, good).
entries.lxxBackground: The LXX uses σῶμα occasionally, but Hebrew thought emphasized the whole person (נֶפֶשׁ, בָּשָׂר) rather than body/soul division. Humans are embodied beings, created good (Gen 1:31). The body is not evil but part of God's good creation. Resurrection hope included the body (Dan 12:2).
entries.intertestamental: Greek influence increased body/soul dualism in some circles. Yet resurrection hope (2 Macc 7) affirmed bodily existence. Wisdom of Solomon shows tension: soul pre-exists and is burdened by body (9:15), yet resurrection is affirmed. Qumran awaited bodily resurrection.
entries.ntUsage: Christ took a body (Heb 10:5). His body was given for us (Luke 22:19; 1 Cor 11:24). Believers' bodies are temples of the Spirit (1 Cor 6:19), living sacrifices (Rom 12:1), and members of Christ (1 Cor 6:15). The church is Christ's body (1 Cor 12:12-27; Eph 1:23; 4:12; Col 1:18, 24). Resurrection is bodily - a 'spiritual body' (1 Cor 15:44). Sexual immorality sins against one's own body (1 Cor 6:18). We await the redemption of our bodies (Rom 8:23).

keyPassages.greek: τὸ σῶμα ὑμῶν ναὸς τοῦ ἐν ὑμῖν ἁγίου πνεύματός ἐστιν
keyPassages.significance: Your body is a temple of the Holy Spirit - dignity of embodiment.

keyPassages.greek: ὑμεῖς δέ ἐστε σῶμα Χριστοῦ καὶ μέλη ἐκ μέρους
keyPassages.significance: You are the body of Christ and individually members - corporate identity.

keyPassages.greek: παραστῆσαι τὰ σώματα ὑμῶν θυσίαν ζῶσαν ἁγίαν
keyPassages.significance: Present your bodies as living sacrifices - bodily worship.

entries.theologicalSignificance: Biblical anthropology affirms embodiment. The incarnation validates the body - the Word became flesh. Resurrection (not immortality of the soul) is the Christian hope - a transformed body, not escape from body. The body is for the Lord and the Lord for the body (1 Cor 6:13). The church as Christ's body emphasizes unity, interdependence, and Christ's headship. Each member matters; diversity serves unity. Bodily resurrection grounds ethics: what we do in the body matters eternally.

relatedWords.relationship: Flesh - overlaps but with different nuances

entries.title: Priest: The Mediator Between God and Humanity
entries.summary: Ἱερεύς is priest - one who mediates between God and people through sacrifice and intercession. Christ is the great High Priest after the order of Melchizedek. All believers are a royal priesthood offering spiritual sacrifices.
entries.classicalGreek: In classical Greek, ἱερεύς meant 'priest' - one who performed sacred rites at temples. Priests sacrificed, maintained temples, and interpreted omens. Each deity had designated priests. The role was cultic rather than pastoral.
entries.lxxBackground: The LXX uses ἱερεύς for כֹּהֵן (kohen). Levitical priests descended from Aaron, offered sacrifices, taught Torah, and mediated between God and Israel (Ex 28-29; Lev 8-9). The high priest alone entered the Holy of Holies annually (Lev 16). Melchizedek was a mysterious priest-king (Gen 14:18; Ps 110:4).
entries.intertestamental: The priesthood continued at the Temple but was often corrupt (1 Macc 7:14). Qumran expected two messiahs - priestly and royal. The Messiah would purify the priesthood. Philo spiritualized priestly concepts. The Hasmoneans controversially combined kingship and priesthood.
entries.ntUsage: Jesus is High Priest (Heb 2:17; 3:1; 4:14-15; 5:5-10). His priesthood is after Melchizedek's order - eternal, superior to Levitical (Heb 7). He offered Himself once for all (Heb 7:27; 9:12; 10:10). He ever lives to intercede (Heb 7:25). Believers are a 'royal priesthood' (1 Pet 2:5, 9), offering spiritual sacrifices (Rom 12:1; Heb 13:15-16). The Levitical system is obsolete (Heb 8:13).

keyPassages.greek: ἔχοντες οὖν ἀρχιερέα μέγαν... Ἰησοῦν τὸν υἱὸν τοῦ θεοῦ... πεπειρασμένον δὲ κατὰ πάντα καθ᾽ ὁμοιότητα χωρὶς ἁμαρτίας
keyPassages.significance: A great high priest who was tempted yet without sin - sympathetic mediator.

keyPassages.greek: ὅθεν καὶ σῴζειν εἰς τὸ παντελὲς δύναται τοὺς προσερχομένους δι᾽ αὐτοῦ τῷ θεῷ, πάντοτε ζῶν εἰς τὸ ἐντυγχάνειν ὑπὲρ αὐτῶν
keyPassages.significance: Able to save completely because He always lives to intercede.

keyPassages.greek: ὑμεῖς δὲ γένος ἐκλεκτόν, βασίλειον ἱεράτευμα
keyPassages.significance: You are a chosen race, a royal priesthood - believers' priestly identity.

entries.theologicalSignificance: Christ's priesthood fulfills and surpasses the old covenant. Unlike Levitical priests, He is sinless, eternal, and His sacrifice needs no repetition. His priesthood is based on God's oath (Ps 110:4), not genealogy. He is both priest and sacrifice. His ongoing intercession assures perseverance. The 'priesthood of all believers' means direct access to God through Christ and service/sacrifice by all Christians - not that clergy are unnecessary, but that all believers are ministers.

entries.title: Temple: The Dwelling Place of God
entries.summary: Ναός is temple or sanctuary - specifically the inner sanctuary where deity dwells. Christ's body is the temple; believers individually and corporately are God's temple. The Spirit indwells this living temple.
entries.classicalGreek: In classical Greek, ναός meant the inner shrine of a temple where the deity's image resided, distinct from ἱερόν (the whole temple complex). It was the sacred dwelling place of the god, accessible only to priests.
entries.lxxBackground: The LXX uses ναός for הֵיכָל (hekal) - the temple building, especially the Holy Place. God's presence dwelt in the Temple (1 Kings 8:10-11). Yet Solomon acknowledged heaven cannot contain God (1 Kings 8:27). The Temple was destroyed (586 BC) and rebuilt, but the glory didn't return as before.
entries.intertestamental: The Second Temple lacked the Shekinah glory and the ark. Yet it remained central to Jewish identity. Qumran saw themselves as a spiritual temple. Expectation grew for a future, glorious temple (Ezek 40-48). The Temple's destruction (AD 70) was devastating.
entries.ntUsage: Jesus spoke of His body as the temple (John 2:19-21). Believers are God's temple (1 Cor 3:16-17; 6:19; 2 Cor 6:16). The church is built into a holy temple (Eph 2:21). The veil was torn at Christ's death (Matt 27:51). The new Jerusalem needs no temple - God and Lamb are its temple (Rev 21:22). The heavenly temple appears in Revelation (Rev 7:15; 11:19; 15:5-8).

keyPassages.greek: λύσατε τὸν ναὸν τοῦτον καὶ ἐν τρισὶν ἡμέραις ἐγερῶ αὐτόν... ἐκεῖνος δὲ ἔλεγεν περὶ τοῦ ναοῦ τοῦ σώματος αὐτοῦ
keyPassages.significance: Destroy this temple - He spoke of the temple of His body.

keyPassages.greek: οὐκ οἴδατε ὅτι ναὸς θεοῦ ἐστε καὶ τὸ πνεῦμα τοῦ θεοῦ οἰκεῖ ἐν ὑμῖν
keyPassages.significance: You are God's temple and God's Spirit dwells in you - corporate temple.

keyPassages.greek: ἐν ᾧ πᾶσα οἰκοδομὴ συναρμολογουμένη αὔξει εἰς ναὸν ἅγιον ἐν κυρίῳ
keyPassages.significance: The whole structure grows into a holy temple - the church as living temple.

entries.theologicalSignificance: The temple theme traces God's dwelling with humanity: Garden → Tabernacle → Temple → Jesus → Church → New Creation. Christ is the true temple - God dwelling with humanity in person. Through the Spirit, believers become living temples, individually and corporately. This implies holiness (don't defile God's temple, 1 Cor 3:17), access (the veil is torn), and mission (we are God's presence in the world). The ultimate hope is not a rebuilt earthly temple but God dwelling directly with His people (Rev 21:3, 22).

entries.title: Sacrifice: The Offering That Atones and Consecrates
entries.summary: Θυσία is sacrifice - an offering to God. OT sacrifices pointed to Christ's once-for-all sacrifice. Believers now offer spiritual sacrifices: praise, good deeds, and their very lives. Sacrifice expresses worship, atonement, and consecration.
entries.classicalGreek: In classical Greek, θυσία meant 'sacrifice' - an offering to the gods, usually involving the slaughter of animals. Sacrifices accompanied prayers, sought divine favor, and maintained relationship with deities. The practice was universal in ancient religion.
entries.lxxBackground: The LXX uses θυσία for זֶבַח (zebach) - slaughtered offering. The Levitical system included burnt offerings (עֹלָה), peace offerings (שֶׁלֶם), sin offerings (חַטָּאת), and guilt offerings (אָשָׁם). Sacrifice dealt with sin (Lev 17:11), expressed worship, and maintained covenant relationship. Yet prophets warned that sacrifice without obedience was worthless (1 Sam 15:22; Isa 1:11-17; Hos 6:6).
entries.intertestamental: Temple sacrifices continued until AD 70. Some groups (Qumran) substituted prayer and community life for Temple sacrifice. Suffering was seen as potentially atoning. The Maccabean martyrs' deaths were interpreted sacrificially (4 Macc 17:22).
entries.ntUsage: Christ offered Himself as sacrifice (Eph 5:2; Heb 9:26; 10:12). His sacrifice was once for all (Heb 7:27; 9:28; 10:10). Animal sacrifices are superseded (Heb 10:1-18). Believers offer: bodies as living sacrifices (Rom 12:1), praise (Heb 13:15), good works (Heb 13:16), financial gifts (Phil 4:18), and faith itself (Phil 2:17). God desires mercy, not sacrifice (Matt 9:13; 12:7). Christ is our Passover sacrificed for us (1 Cor 5:7).

keyPassages.greek: Χριστὸς ἠγάπησεν ἡμᾶς καὶ παρέδωκεν ἑαυτὸν ὑπὲρ ἡμῶν προσφορὰν καὶ θυσίαν τῷ θεῷ
keyPassages.significance: Christ loved us and gave Himself as an offering and sacrifice to God.

keyPassages.greek: οὗτος δὲ μίαν ὑπὲρ ἁμαρτιῶν προσενέγκας θυσίαν εἰς τὸ διηνεκές
keyPassages.significance: He offered for all time a single sacrifice for sins - finality of Christ's work.

keyPassages.greek: παραστῆσαι τὰ σώματα ὑμῶν θυσίαν ζῶσαν ἁγίαν εὐάρεστον τῷ θεῷ
keyPassages.significance: Present your bodies as a living sacrifice - the believer's responsive worship.

entries.theologicalSignificance: Sacrifice deals with the problem of sin. Christ's sacrifice accomplishes what animal sacrifices symbolized - actual atonement, propitiation, and reconciliation. It is unrepeatable because it was complete. The Lord's Supper commemorates but does not repeat the sacrifice. Christian sacrifice is now responsive - we offer ourselves because He first offered Himself. Sacrifice remains costly: true worship costs something (2 Sam 24:24). The language of sacrifice permeates Christian understanding of Christ's death and believers' devotion.

entries.title: Elect: Chosen by God for Salvation
entries.summary: Ἐκλεκτός means 'chosen' or 'elect' - selected from among others. God chose Israel; Christ is the Elect One; believers are the elect. Election is rooted in God's sovereign grace, executed in Christ, and results in holiness and mission.
entries.classicalGreek: In classical Greek, ἐκλεκτός (from ἐκλέγομαι, 'to choose out') meant 'chosen, select, excellent.' It described things or persons picked for special quality or purpose. The word emphasized deliberate selection from among alternatives.
entries.lxxBackground: The LXX uses ἐκλεκτός for בָּחִיר (bachir). God chose Abraham (Neh 9:7), Israel (Deut 7:6; 14:2; Isa 45:4), David (Ps 89:3), and the Servant (Isa 42:1). Election was based not on merit but on God's love (Deut 7:7-8). The chosen people had a mission to the nations.
entries.intertestamental: Election remained central to Jewish identity. Various groups claimed to be the true elect (Qumran especially). The elect would be vindicated at judgment. Apocalyptic literature spoke of the elect preserved through tribulation.
entries.ntUsage: Christ is 'the Elect One' (Luke 9:35; 23:35; 1 Pet 2:4, 6). Believers are elect (Rom 8:33; Col 3:12; 1 Pet 1:1; 2:9). God chose us before creation (Eph 1:4). Election is 'in Christ' (Eph 1:4), according to foreknowledge (Rom 8:29; 1 Pet 1:2), unto holiness (Eph 1:4), and for good works (Eph 2:10). The elect cannot be separated from Christ (Rom 8:33-39). Election is confirmed through sanctification (2 Pet 1:10). Angels are also elect (1 Tim 5:21).

keyPassages.greek: καθὼς ἐξελέξατο ἡμᾶς ἐν αὐτῷ πρὸ καταβολῆς κόσμου εἶναι ἡμᾶς ἁγίους
keyPassages.significance: He chose us in Him before the foundation of the world - eternal election.

keyPassages.greek: τίς ἐγκαλέσει κατὰ ἐκλεκτῶν θεοῦ; θεὸς ὁ δικαιῶν
keyPassages.significance: Who shall bring any charge against God's elect? - security of the chosen.

keyPassages.greek: ὑμεῖς δὲ γένος ἐκλεκτόν
keyPassages.significance: You are a chosen race - corporate identity of the elect.

entries.theologicalSignificance: Election is God's sovereign, gracious choice before creation. It is not based on foreseen faith or merit but on God's purpose and grace (Rom 9:11-13; 2 Tim 1:9). Election is always 'in Christ' - He is the Elect One in whom we are chosen. Far from producing pride, election humbles: we contribute nothing. Far from producing passivity, it assures: God's purpose cannot fail. Election is unto holiness and service, not merely heaven. The doctrine comforts believers (God's choice is unchanging) and calls sinners (everyone who comes to Christ finds they were chosen).

entries.title: Call: The Divine Summons to Salvation
entries.summary: Καλέω means 'to call' - to name, invite, or summon. God's call brings sinners to salvation, assigns vocation, and creates identity. The called are the church (ἐκκλησία, 'the called out'). God's call is effectual and irrevocable.
entries.classicalGreek: In classical Greek, καλέω meant 'to call, name, summon, invite.' It was used for naming children, inviting guests, summoning to court, and calling to military service. The word implied authoritative address expecting response.
entries.lxxBackground: The LXX uses καλέω for קָרָא (qara). God calls into being what doesn't exist (Isa 41:4; 48:13). He called Abraham (Isa 51:2), Israel (Isa 43:1), the Servant (Isa 49:1), and individuals by name. Divine calling implies purpose and relationship.
entries.intertestamental: Calling language continued for God's summons and human response. The righteous were 'called' to covenant faithfulness. Prophetic calling was God's authoritative commission. Calling included both privilege and responsibility.
entries.ntUsage: God calls sinners to salvation (Rom 8:30; 9:24; 1 Cor 1:9; Gal 1:6; 1 Thess 2:12). Those called are 'saints' (Rom 1:7; 1 Cor 1:2). The call is effectual - those called come (Rom 8:30). God calls to His kingdom (1 Thess 2:12), to peace (1 Cor 7:15), to freedom (Gal 5:13), to holiness (1 Thess 4:7), and to hope (Eph 4:4). Calling includes vocation (1 Cor 7:20). The gifts and call are irrevocable (Rom 11:29). Believers must live worthy of their calling (Eph 4:1).

keyPassages.greek: οὓς δὲ προώρισεν, τούτους καὶ ἐκάλεσεν· καὶ οὓς ἐκάλεσεν, τούτους καὶ ἐδικαίωσεν
keyPassages.significance: Those He predestined He also called; those He called He justified - golden chain.

keyPassages.greek: πιστὸς ὁ θεὸς δι᾽ οὗ ἐκλήθητε εἰς κοινωνίαν τοῦ υἱοῦ αὐτοῦ
keyPassages.significance: God is faithful, by whom you were called into fellowship with His Son.

keyPassages.greek: παρακαλῶ οὖν ὑμᾶς... ἀξίως περιπατῆσαι τῆς κλήσεως ἧς ἐκλήθητε
keyPassages.significance: Walk worthy of the calling to which you have been called.

entries.theologicalSignificance: God's call is powerful and effective. It brings about what it commands. The 'general call' (gospel proclamation to all) becomes 'effectual call' when the Spirit makes it effective in the elect. Calling links election (before time) with justification (in time) - Romans 8:30's 'golden chain.' The church is literally 'the called-out ones' (ἐκκλησία). Calling creates identity: we are 'called saints,' not 'called to become saints.' Vocation (calling to work/service) flows from salvation calling. God's call demands corresponding conduct - living worthy of who we've been made.

entries.title: Fulfill: The Completion of God's Purposes
entries.summary: Πληρόω means 'to fill' or 'fulfill' - to complete, accomplish, or bring to full expression. Christ fulfilled the Scriptures, the law, and prophecy. Believers are filled with the Spirit and must fulfill their calling. God's purposes reach their intended goal.
entries.classicalGreek: In classical Greek, πληρόω meant 'to fill, make full' - whether a container, a number, or a time period. It extended to 'complete, accomplish' what was intended. The word implied reaching fullness or intended completion.
entries.lxxBackground: The LXX uses πληρόω for מָלֵא (male, 'to fill'). Time is fulfilled (Gen 25:24). Commands are fulfilled/obeyed. Prophecies are fulfilled when they come to pass. The land is filled with God's glory (Num 14:21). Filling implies completion of divine purpose.
entries.intertestamental: Fulfillment language applied to prophecy and divine promises. Expectations grew for eschatological fulfillment - when God would finally accomplish His purposes. The Messiah would bring fulfillment of Israel's hopes.
entries.ntUsage: Christ came to fulfill the law and prophets (Matt 5:17). Events happened 'to fulfill' Scripture (Matt 1:22; 2:15, 17, 23; 4:14; etc.). The time was fulfilled (Mark 1:15; Gal 4:4). Believers are to be filled with the Spirit (Eph 5:18), with knowledge (Col 1:9), with joy (John 16:24), and with the fullness of God (Eph 3:19). The law is fulfilled in love (Rom 13:8, 10; Gal 5:14). God is able to fulfill His promises (Rom 4:21).

keyPassages.greek: μὴ νομίσητε ὅτι ἦλθον καταλῦσαι τὸν νόμον ἢ τοὺς προφήτας· οὐκ ἦλθον καταλῦσαι ἀλλὰ πληρῶσαι
keyPassages.significance: I came not to abolish but to fulfill - Christ completes God's revelation.

keyPassages.greek: ὅτε δὲ ἦλθεν τὸ πλήρωμα τοῦ χρόνου, ἐξαπέστειλεν ὁ θεὸς τὸν υἱὸν αὐτοῦ
keyPassages.significance: When the fullness of time came, God sent His Son - salvation history reaches climax.

keyPassages.greek: πληροῦσθε ἐν πνεύματι
keyPassages.significance: Be filled with the Spirit - ongoing spiritual fullness.

entries.theologicalSignificance: Fulfillment is central to NT theology. Christ is the goal toward which the OT pointed. He didn't abolish but brought to completion - filling the law with its intended meaning and accomplishing what it demanded. Prophecy reaches its 'yes' in Him (2 Cor 1:20). This validates the OT as Christian Scripture while showing its incompleteness without Christ. The present age is the era of fulfillment begun but not yet consummated. Believers experience the 'already' of fulfillment while awaiting the 'not yet' of final completion.

relatedWords.relationship: To fill up, complete (1 Cor 16:17; Gal 6:2)

entries.title: Disciple: The Learner Who Follows the Master
entries.summary: Μαθητής is disciple - a learner who follows a teacher. Jesus called disciples to follow Him, learn from Him, and become like Him. Discipleship means total allegiance, ongoing learning, and multiplication through making other disciples.
entries.classicalGreek: In classical Greek, μαθητής meant 'learner, pupil, student' - one who attached to a teacher to learn. Philosophers had disciples who learned their teaching and way of life. The relationship involved both intellectual learning and imitation of life.
entries.lxxBackground: The LXX rarely uses μαθητής. The concept appears in prophetic schools (sons of the prophets) and wisdom teaching. Isaiah 8:16 refers to disciples. The Torah was to be taught (Deut 6:7), implying a teaching-learning relationship. The righteous learned God's ways.
entries.intertestamental: Rabbinic Judaism developed formal discipleship. Disciples attached to rabbis, learned Torah, and served their masters. The goal was eventually to become teachers themselves. Discipleship was total commitment, including physical service.
entries.ntUsage: Jesus called disciples (Matt 4:19; Mark 1:17). The Twelve were disciples in a special sense (Matt 10:1). The term extends to all followers (Acts 6:1-2, 7; 9:1, 10, 19, 26). Discipleship costs: taking up the cross (Luke 14:27), forsaking all (Luke 14:33), and following (John 8:31; 12:26). The Great Commission is to 'make disciples' (Matt 28:19). Disciples are characterized by love (John 13:35), fruitfulness (John 15:8), and continuing in Jesus' word (John 8:31).

keyPassages.greek: πορευθέντες οὖν μαθητεύσατε πάντα τὰ ἔθνη
keyPassages.significance: Go and make disciples of all nations - mission defined as disciple-making.

keyPassages.greek: ὅστις οὐ βαστάζει τὸν σταυρὸν ἑαυτοῦ καὶ ἔρχεται ὀπίσω μου, οὐ δύναται εἶναί μου μαθητής
keyPassages.significance: Whoever does not bear his cross and come after me cannot be my disciple.

keyPassages.greek: ἐν τούτῳ γνώσονται πάντες ὅτι ἐμοὶ μαθηταί ἐστε, ἐὰν ἀγάπην ἔχητε ἐν ἀλλήλοις
keyPassages.significance: By this all will know you are my disciples - if you have love for one another.

entries.theologicalSignificance: Discipleship is the normal Christian life. Unlike Greek students who eventually graduated, Jesus' disciples remain learners for life. Discipleship is relational (with Jesus), transformational (becoming like Him), and missional (making other disciples). It demands absolute loyalty - above family, possessions, and self. The marks of discipleship are love, obedience, perseverance, and fruitfulness. The church's mission is not merely to make converts but disciples - those who follow, learn, and obey all Christ commanded.

relatedWords.relationship: To make disciples, become a disciple (Matt 28:19)

entries.shortDef: to conquer, overcome, prevail, be victorious
entries.title: Overcome: Victory Through Christ
entries.summary: Νικάω means 'to conquer' or 'overcome' - to gain victory in conflict. Christ has overcome the world; believers overcome through Him. Revelation's promises are 'to the one who overcomes.' Victory is already won yet must be appropriated through faith and perseverance.
entries.classicalGreek: In classical Greek, νικάω meant 'to conquer, defeat, win.' It was used for military victory, athletic triumph, and legal success. Nike was the goddess of victory. The word implied successful struggle against opposition.
entries.lxxBackground: The LXX uses νικάω occasionally for victory in battle. God gives victory (2 Sam 23:10, 12). The theme of divine victory pervades Scripture: God defeats enemies, vindicates His people, and will ultimately triumph.
entries.intertestamental: Victory language intensified in apocalyptic contexts. God would finally conquer evil. The righteous who endured persecution would be vindicated and share in divine victory. Martyrs especially would triumph.
entries.ntUsage: Christ has overcome the world (John 16:33) and the evil one (1 John 2:13-14). Believers overcome through faith (1 John 5:4-5), the blood of the Lamb and their testimony (Rev 12:11), and perseverance. Revelation's letters promise blessings 'to the one who overcomes' (Rev 2:7, 11, 17, 26; 3:5, 12, 21). The Lamb conquers (Rev 5:5; 17:14). Good overcomes evil (Rom 12:21). Love is supreme - we are 'more than conquerors' (Rom 8:37).

keyPassages.greek: θαρσεῖτε, ἐγὼ νενίκηκα τὸν κόσμον
keyPassages.significance: Take heart; I have overcome the world - Christ's victory complete.

keyPassages.greek: αὕτη ἐστὶν ἡ νίκη ἡ νικήσασα τὸν κόσμον, ἡ πίστις ἡμῶν
keyPassages.significance: This is the victory that has overcome the world - our faith.

keyPassages.greek: αὐτοὶ ἐνίκησαν αὐτὸν διὰ τὸ αἷμα τοῦ ἀρνίου καὶ διὰ τὸν λόγον τῆς μαρτυρίας αὐτῶν
keyPassages.significance: They conquered him by the blood of the Lamb and their testimony.

entries.theologicalSignificance: Christian victory is paradoxical. It comes through apparent defeat - the cross. The Lamb conquers by being slain (Rev 5:5-6). Believers overcome not by worldly power but by faith, testimony, and willingness to suffer. Victory is already accomplished in Christ; believers appropriate it through faith and perseverance. The overcomer promises in Revelation encourage persecuted believers: present suffering leads to eternal glory. Evil will not have the last word. Those who endure to the end will reign with Christ.

relatedWords.relationship: To be more than a conqueror (Rom 8:37)

entries.title: Temptation/Trial: The Test That Proves or Exposes
entries.summary: Πειρασμός can mean either 'temptation' (enticement to sin) or 'trial' (testing that proves faith). God tests but doesn't tempt; Satan tempts. Trials produce endurance; temptation must be resisted. Christ was tempted yet without sin and helps the tempted.
entries.classicalGreek: In classical Greek, πειρασμός (from πειράζω, 'to try, test') meant 'trial, test, experiment.' It was neutral - the test could have positive or negative outcomes. Testing could prove quality or expose weakness.
entries.lxxBackground: The LXX uses πειρασμός for נִסָּיוֹן (nisayon). God tested Abraham (Gen 22:1), Israel in the wilderness (Deut 8:2), and believers generally (Ps 26:2). Testing proves faith. Israel 'tested' God at Massah (Ex 17:7; Ps 95:8-9) - demanding proof of His presence. Testing can be from God (proving) or against God (doubting).
entries.intertestamental: Testing was seen as purifying the righteous (Sirach 2:1-5; Wisdom 3:5-6). Trials would intensify before the end. The pious were tested to demonstrate their faithfulness. Satan emerged more clearly as tempter.
entries.ntUsage: Jesus was tempted by Satan (Matt 4:1-11; Heb 4:15) yet without sin. We pray 'lead us not into temptation' (Matt 6:13). God tempts no one (Jas 1:13); temptation comes from one's own desires (Jas 1:14-15). Yet God permits trials (1 Pet 1:6; Jas 1:2-4). Trials produce endurance and proven character (Rom 5:3-4; Jas 1:3). God provides escape from temptation (1 Cor 10:13). Christ helps the tempted (Heb 2:18; 4:15-16).

keyPassages.greek: πᾶσαν χαρὰν ἡγήσασθε... ὅταν πειρασμοῖς περιπέσητε ποικίλοις, γινώσκοντες ὅτι τὸ δοκίμιον ὑμῶν τῆς πίστεως κατεργάζεται ὑπομονήν
keyPassages.significance: Count it all joy when you meet trials - testing produces endurance.

keyPassages.greek: πειρασμὸς ὑμᾶς οὐκ εἴληφεν εἰ μὴ ἀνθρώπινος· πιστὸς δὲ ὁ θεὸς... ἀλλὰ ποιήσει σὺν τῷ πειρασμῷ καὶ τὴν ἔκβασιν
keyPassages.significance: God is faithful and will provide the way of escape with the temptation.

keyPassages.greek: πεπειρασμένον δὲ κατὰ πάντα καθ᾽ ὁμοιότητα χωρὶς ἁμαρτίας
keyPassages.significance: Tempted in every way as we are, yet without sin - sympathetic high priest.

entries.theologicalSignificance: The dual meaning of πειρασμός (temptation/trial) requires careful interpretation. God tests to prove and strengthen faith; He never entices to sin. Satan tempts to destroy faith. The same circumstance can be both - a trial from God's perspective, a temptation from Satan's. Christ's victory over temptation enables His people to overcome. We should neither seek testing (pray 'lead us not') nor be surprised by it (count it joy). God limits and provides escape. Character is forged through testing endured.

entries.title: Confess: Public Declaration of Faith
entries.summary: Ὁμολογέω means 'to confess' or 'acknowledge' - to say the same thing, agree, or declare publicly. Confession includes professing faith in Christ, acknowledging sin, and declaring allegiance. Confession with the mouth accompanies belief in the heart.
entries.classicalGreek: In classical Greek, ὁμολογέω (from ὁμός 'same' + λέγω 'speak') meant 'to say the same thing, agree, concede, promise.' It implied agreement between parties, public acknowledgment, or binding commitment. Legal and contractual usage was common.
entries.lxxBackground: The LXX uses ὁμολογέω for יָדָה (yadah) in the sense of praise and thanksgiving (confessing God's goodness). Confession of sin also appears (Lev 5:5; 16:21). To confess is to declare openly what one believes or has done.
entries.intertestamental: Confession of faith distinguished Israel from pagans. Martyrs confessed God before oppressors. Confession of sin was part of repentance. The Shema (Deut 6:4) was the fundamental confession.
entries.ntUsage: Confess Jesus as Lord (Rom 10:9-10; Phil 2:11). Confess Christ before people (Matt 10:32). The good confession (1 Tim 6:12-13; Heb 3:1; 4:14). Confess sins to God (1 John 1:9) and one another (Jas 5:16). Deny vs. confess Christ (Matt 10:32-33; 2 Tim 2:12; 1 John 2:23). Demons confess Christ's identity (Mark 1:24; 3:11; 5:7). Jesus confessed before Pilate (1 Tim 6:13).

keyPassages.greek: ἐὰν ὁμολογήσῃς ἐν τῷ στόματί σου κύριον Ἰησοῦν καὶ πιστεύσῃς ἐν τῇ καρδίᾳ σου... σωθήσῃ
keyPassages.significance: If you confess with your mouth Jesus as Lord and believe... you will be saved.

keyPassages.greek: ἐὰν ὁμολογῶμεν τὰς ἁμαρτίας ἡμῶν, πιστός ἐστιν καὶ δίκαιος, ἵνα ἀφῇ ἡμῖν τὰς ἁμαρτίας
keyPassages.significance: If we confess our sins, He is faithful and just to forgive us.

keyPassages.greek: πᾶς οὖν ὅστις ὁμολογήσει ἐν ἐμοὶ ἔμπροσθεν τῶν ἀνθρώπων, ὁμολογήσω κἀγὼ ἐν αὐτῷ
keyPassages.significance: Everyone who confesses me before others, I will confess before my Father.

entries.theologicalSignificance: Confession unites mouth and heart. Belief is invisible; confession makes it public. To confess is to take a stand, to be identified with Christ whatever the cost. The earliest Christian confession was 'Jesus is Lord' (Rom 10:9; 1 Cor 12:3) - a statement with both theological content and political implications (Caesar is not Lord). Confession of sin (agreeing with God about our sin) is the path to forgiveness. Both confessions are relational: acknowledging who Christ is and who we are before Him.

relatedWords.relationship: To deny - the opposite of confess (Matt 10:33)

entries.title: Fruit: The Evidence of Life and Faith
entries.summary: Καρπός is fruit - the natural produce of a plant, and metaphorically the outcome of life, actions, and character. Good trees bear good fruit; believers bear the fruit of the Spirit. Fruit-bearing demonstrates genuine discipleship and glorifies God.
entries.classicalGreek: In classical Greek, καρπός meant 'fruit' - the edible produce of trees and plants. Metaphorically it extended to any result, benefit, or outcome. Fruit represented the natural product of something's essential nature.
entries.lxxBackground: The LXX uses καρπός for פְּרִי (peri). The righteous are like fruitful trees (Ps 1:3; Jer 17:8). Israel is God's vineyard expected to bear fruit (Isa 5:1-7). 'Fruit of the womb' means children (Gen 30:2; Ps 127:3). Fruit represents the outcome of one's ways - righteousness or wickedness.
entries.intertestamental: Fruit imagery continued. The righteous bear good fruit; the wicked bear evil. Wisdom produces fruit (Sirach 6:19). The tree metaphor applied to individuals and nations. Fruit-bearing was evidence of covenant faithfulness.
entries.ntUsage: John the Baptist demanded fruit of repentance (Matt 3:8). Trees are known by fruit (Matt 7:16-20; 12:33). The vine and branches imagery: abiding produces fruit (John 15:1-8). The fruit of the Spirit (Gal 5:22-23) contrasts with works of the flesh. Paul seeks fruit for the Philippians' account (Phil 4:17). Fruit of righteousness (Heb 12:11; Jas 3:18), fruit of lips (Heb 13:15). The unfruitful are cut off (John 15:2; Matt 3:10).

keyPassages.greek: ὁ δὲ καρπὸς τοῦ πνεύματός ἐστιν ἀγάπη χαρὰ εἰρήνη, μακροθυμία χρηστότης ἀγαθωσύνη, πίστις πραΰτης ἐγκράτεια
keyPassages.significance: The fruit of the Spirit is love, joy, peace... - singular fruit, multiple expressions.

keyPassages.greek: ἐγώ εἰμι ἡ ἄμπελος, ὑμεῖς τὰ κλήματα. ὁ μένων ἐν ἐμοὶ κἀγὼ ἐν αὐτῷ οὗτος φέρει καρπὸν πολύν
keyPassages.significance: I am the vine, you are the branches - abiding produces much fruit.

keyPassages.greek: ἀπὸ τῶν καρπῶν αὐτῶν ἐπιγνώσεσθε αὐτούς... πᾶν δένδρον ἀγαθὸν καρποὺς καλοὺς ποιεῖ
keyPassages.significance: You will recognize them by their fruits - fruit reveals nature.

entries.theologicalSignificance: Fruit is evidence, not cause, of life. A tree doesn't become good by producing good fruit; it produces good fruit because it is good. Similarly, works don't save but genuine salvation produces works. The 'fruit of the Spirit' is singular - a unified character manifested in various virtues, produced by the Spirit, not self-effort. Fruit-bearing requires abiding in Christ. Fruitlessness is serious - fruitless branches are removed (John 15:2). Much fruit glorifies the Father and proves discipleship (John 15:8). Fruit includes character, converts, and praise.

entries.title: Work: The Deeds That Demonstrate Faith
