entries.summary: Ἔργον is work or deed - any action or task. The NT discusses 'works of the law' (rejected for justification), God's works, Christ's works, and believers' good works. Faith without works is dead; saved by grace, we are created for good works.
entries.classicalGreek: In classical Greek, ἔργον meant 'work, deed, action' - any activity or its product. It covered manual labor, artistic works, military action, and moral conduct. Works revealed character and produced results.
entries.lxxBackground: The LXX uses ἔργον for מַעֲשֶׂה (maaseh). God's works in creation (Gen 2:2-3) and redemption (Ps 66:5; 111:2-4). Human works are judged (Eccl 12:14). 'Work of their hands' could mean idols or labor. The righteous are known by their works.
entries.intertestamental: Works-righteousness developed in some circles: accumulating merit through law-keeping. Yet dependence on God's grace remained in others. Works would be judged at the final accounting. The relationship of works to salvation was debated.
entries.ntUsage: 'Works of the law' don't justify (Rom 3:20, 28; Gal 2:16; 3:2, 5, 10). Yet faith without works is dead (Jas 2:17, 26). Believers are created for good works (Eph 2:10). Works will be judged (2 Cor 5:10; Rev 20:12-13). Christ's works testify to Him (John 5:36; 10:25, 32, 38). God's work is to believe (John 6:29). Work out salvation with fear (Phil 2:12). Faith works through love (Gal 5:6).

keyPassages.greek: τῇ γὰρ χάριτί ἐστε σεσῳσμένοι διὰ πίστεως... οὐκ ἐξ ἔργων... αὐτοῦ γάρ ἐσμεν ποίημα, κτισθέντες... ἐπὶ ἔργοις ἀγαθοῖς
keyPassages.significance: Saved by grace through faith, not works - created for good works.

keyPassages.greek: οὕτως καὶ ἡ πίστις, ἐὰν μὴ ἔχῃ ἔργα, νεκρά ἐστιν καθ᾽ ἑαυτήν
keyPassages.significance: Faith by itself, if it does not have works, is dead.

keyPassages.greek: ἵνα λυτρώσηται ἡμᾶς ἀπὸ πάσης ἀνομίας καὶ καθαρίσῃ ἑαυτῷ λαὸν περιούσιον, ζηλωτὴν καλῶν ἔργων
keyPassages.significance: To purify for Himself a people zealous for good works.

entries.theologicalSignificance: Paul and James don't contradict. Paul opposes works as grounds of justification; James insists genuine faith produces works. 'Works of the law' (religious performance to earn salvation) differ from 'good works' (grateful response to salvation). We are not saved BY works but FOR works (Eph 2:10). Works will be evaluated at judgment, not for salvation but for reward (1 Cor 3:12-15). Good works glorify God (Matt 5:16) and benefit neighbors. The integration of faith and works, grace and obedience, is essential to NT ethics.

entries.shortDef: Gehenna, hell, place of final punishment
entries.title: Gehenna: The Place of Final Judgment
entries.summary: Γέεννα (from Hebrew גֵּיא הִנֹּם, Valley of Hinnom) is the place of final punishment - what Jesus called 'hell.' It is characterized by unquenchable fire and eternal separation from God. Jesus warned about Gehenna more than anyone else in Scripture.
entries.classicalGreek: Γέεννα is not a classical Greek word. It is a transliteration of the Hebrew geographical term 'Valley of Hinnom' (גֵּי הִנֹּם), which became a term for final punishment.
entries.lxxBackground: The Valley of Hinnom (Jer 7:31-32; 19:2-6; 32:35) south of Jerusalem was where children were sacrificed to Molech. Josiah defiled it (2 Kings 23:10). It became a garbage dump with perpetual fires. The prophets predicted judgment there (Jer 7:32; Isa 66:24).
entries.intertestamental: Gehenna developed into the place of eschatological punishment (1 Enoch 27:2; 54:1-6; 90:26-27; 4 Ezra 7:36). It was contrasted with paradise or Abraham's bosom. Fire and destruction characterized it. It became the standard term for final judgment of the wicked.
entries.ntUsage: Jesus speaks of Gehenna frequently (Matt 5:22, 29-30; 10:28; 18:9; 23:15, 33; Mark 9:43, 45, 47; Luke 12:5). It is better to enter life maimed than go to Gehenna with whole body (Mark 9:43-47). Fear Him who can destroy both soul and body in Gehenna (Matt 10:28). Unquenchable fire (Mark 9:43, 48). Eternal punishment (Matt 25:46). James 3:6 mentions the tongue set on fire by Gehenna.

keyPassages.greek: καλόν ἐστίν σε... εἰσελθεῖν εἰς τὴν ζωὴν ἢ... βληθῆναι εἰς τὴν γέενναν, εἰς τὸ πῦρ τὸ ἄσβεστον... ὅπου ὁ σκώληξ αὐτῶν οὐ τελευτᾷ
keyPassages.significance: Better to enter life than be thrown into Gehenna, unquenchable fire.

keyPassages.greek: φοβεῖσθε δὲ μᾶλλον τὸν δυνάμενον καὶ ψυχὴν καὶ σῶμα ἀπολέσαι ἐν γεέννῃ
keyPassages.significance: Fear Him who can destroy both soul and body in Gehenna.

keyPassages.greek: ἀπελεύσονται οὗτοι εἰς κόλασιν αἰώνιον, οἱ δὲ δίκαιοι εἰς ζωὴν αἰώνιον
keyPassages.significance: These will go away into eternal punishment - duration matches eternal life.

entries.theologicalSignificance: Jesus' warnings about Gehenna are the clearest biblical teaching on final judgment. The language is severe: fire, destruction, eternal duration. This is not annihilation (eternal punishment implies ongoing existence) nor temporary purgation. Gehenna motivates evangelism (we warn because judgment is real), gratitude (we are saved from wrath), and holiness (radical measures are warranted to avoid hell). The doctrine is difficult but Jesus' teaching is clear. Gehenna is the ultimate consequence of rejecting God - eternal separation from the source of all good.

relatedWords.relationship: Hades - place of the dead, distinct from Gehenna
Tartarus - place of fallen angels (2 Pet 2:4)

entries.shortDef: Hades, realm of the dead, underworld
entries.title: Hades: The Realm of the Dead
entries.summary: ᾍδης is Hades - the realm of the dead, the intermediate state between death and resurrection. It is not the same as Gehenna (final judgment). The gates of Hades cannot prevail against the church. Christ holds the keys of Death and Hades.
entries.classicalGreek: In classical Greek, ᾅδης (from ἀ-ιδεῖν, 'unseen') was the god of the underworld and the underworld itself - the realm of the dead. All deceased went there, regardless of moral character. It was shadowy, gloomy, and final.
entries.lxxBackground: The LXX uses ᾅδης for שְׁאוֹל (Sheol) - the place of the dead. All died and went to Sheol (Gen 37:35; Ps 89:48). It was described as dark, silent, and cut off from the living and from praising God (Ps 6:5; 88:3-12; 115:17). Later texts hint at differentiation within Sheol.
entries.intertestamental: Differentiation developed between the righteous and wicked in Sheol/Hades. 1 Enoch describes separate compartments. The righteous await resurrection in comfort; the wicked in torment. Paradise and Abraham's bosom designate the blessed area.
entries.ntUsage: Jesus descended to Hades (Acts 2:27, 31). The gates of Hades won't prevail against the church (Matt 16:18). The rich man in Hades (Luke 16:23). Death and Hades are personified (Rev 1:18; 6:8; 20:13-14). Christ holds their keys (Rev 1:18). Death and Hades are thrown into the lake of fire (Rev 20:14) - they are penultimate, not final.

keyPassages.greek: πύλαι ᾅδου οὐ κατισχύσουσιν αὐτῆς
keyPassages.significance: The gates of Hades will not prevail against it - death cannot stop the church.

keyPassages.greek: ἔχω τὰς κλεῖς τοῦ θανάτου καὶ τοῦ ᾅδου
keyPassages.significance: I have the keys of Death and Hades - Christ's sovereignty over death.

keyPassages.greek: ὁ θάνατος καὶ ὁ ᾅδης ἐβλήθησαν εἰς τὴν λίμνην τοῦ πυρός
keyPassages.significance: Death and Hades were thrown into the lake of fire - their abolition.

entries.theologicalSignificance: Hades is the intermediate state, not the final state. It is temporary, awaiting resurrection and final judgment. The distinction between Hades (intermediate) and Gehenna (final) is important. Christ's resurrection broke Hades' power - He holds the keys. For believers, to be 'away from the body' is to be 'with the Lord' (2 Cor 5:8; Phil 1:23) - the blessed aspect of Hades/Paradise. The final enemy, Death (and Hades with it), will be destroyed (1 Cor 15:26; Rev 20:14). The resurrection empties Hades of its occupants for final judgment.

relatedWords.relationship: Gehenna - the final place of judgment

entries.title: Fullness: The Complete Divine Presence
entries.summary: Πλήρωμα is fullness - that which fills or the state of being full. In Christ dwells all the fullness of deity bodily. The church is filled with Christ's fullness. Believers are being filled unto all the fullness of God. Fullness counters any deficiency theology.
entries.classicalGreek: In classical Greek, πλήρωμα meant 'that which fills, fullness, completeness.' It could be active (what fills) or passive (the state of being filled). Ships' crews, cargoes, and full measures were πλήρωμα. The word implied completion and abundance.
entries.lxxBackground: The LXX uses πλήρωμα occasionally. 'The earth is the Lord's and the fullness thereof' (Ps 24:1; 50:12; 89:11). God's glory fills creation. The concept relates to God's complete presence and blessing.
entries.intertestamental: Fullness language appeared in Jewish wisdom speculation and later in Gnostic systems (though NT usage precedes developed Gnosticism). The divine fullness dwelt in Wisdom. In Gnostic systems, πλήρωμα was the totality of divine emanations - which NT teaching counters.
entries.ntUsage: All fullness dwells in Christ (Col 1:19). In Him the fullness of deity dwells bodily (Col 2:9). Believers are filled in Him (Col 2:10). The church is His body, the fullness of Him (Eph 1:23). We are to be filled unto all the fullness of God (Eph 3:19). The fullness of time (Gal 4:4; Eph 1:10). Fullness of blessing (Rom 15:29). Love is the fullness of the law (Rom 13:10). The fullness of the Gentiles (Rom 11:25).

keyPassages.greek: ἐν αὐτῷ κατοικεῖ πᾶν τὸ πλήρωμα τῆς θεότητος σωματικῶς
keyPassages.significance: In Him all the fullness of deity dwells bodily - complete deity in Christ.

keyPassages.greek: ἵνα πληρωθῆτε εἰς πᾶν τὸ πλήρωμα τοῦ θεοῦ
keyPassages.significance: That you may be filled with all the fullness of God - believers' goal.

keyPassages.greek: τὸ σῶμα αὐτοῦ, τὸ πλήρωμα τοῦ πληροῦντος τὰ πάντα ἐν πᾶσιν
keyPassages.significance: The church is His body, the fullness of Him who fills all in all.

entries.theologicalSignificance: Paul's fullness language counters deficiency theologies. Christ is not one emanation among many; ALL fullness dwells in Him. Nothing is lacking; no additional mediators are needed. Believers need not seek fullness elsewhere - they are complete in Him (Col 2:10). The church participates in this fullness. The goal of salvation is being filled with divine fullness - not absorption into God but transformation into Christ's likeness. Fullness is already ours positionally; we grow into experiencing it practically.

entries.title: Beginning: The Origin and Authority of All Things
entries.summary: Ἀρχή means 'beginning' or 'ruler' - the origin, first cause, or governing authority. Christ is both the beginning (origin of creation) and the ruler (over all principalities). 'In the beginning' opens both Genesis and John's Gospel, pointing to Christ's eternal pre-existence.
entries.classicalGreek: In classical Greek, ἀρχή meant 'beginning, origin, first principle' and also 'sovereignty, rule, authority.' Philosophers sought the ἀρχή of all things - the first principle or element. Political ἀρχή meant ruling power. The word bridged cosmology and politics.
entries.lxxBackground: The LXX uses ἀρχή for רֵאשִׁית (reshit, 'beginning') in Genesis 1:1. It also translates terms for rule and dominion. Wisdom was with God 'from the beginning' (Prov 8:22-23). The beginning of wisdom is fear of the Lord (Prov 1:7; 9:10). Rulers exercise ἀρχή.
entries.intertestamental: Speculation about the ἀρχή of creation continued. Angels and cosmic powers were called ἀρχαί (rulers). Wisdom was present at the beginning. The origin of evil was debated. Apocalyptic literature featured celestial rulers.
entries.ntUsage: 'In the beginning was the Word' (John 1:1). Christ is the beginning, firstborn from the dead (Col 1:18). He is the beginning of God's creation (Rev 3:14). Christ existed 'from the beginning' (1 John 1:1; 2:13-14). Principalities and powers (ἀρχαί) are subject to Christ (Rom 8:38; Eph 1:21; 3:10; 6:12; Col 1:16; 2:10, 15). The beginning of signs (John 2:11). The beginning of the gospel (Mark 1:1).

keyPassages.greek: Ἐν ἀρχῇ ἦν ὁ λόγος
keyPassages.significance: In the beginning was the Word - eternal pre-existence of Christ.

keyPassages.greek: ὅς ἐστιν ἀρχή, πρωτότοκος ἐκ τῶν νεκρῶν
keyPassages.significance: He is the beginning, the firstborn from the dead - resurrection origin.

keyPassages.greek: ἡ ἀρχὴ τῆς κτίσεως τοῦ θεοῦ
keyPassages.significance: The beginning of God's creation - origin/ruler of creation.

entries.theologicalSignificance: John 1:1 echoes Genesis 1:1: before creation, Christ existed. He is not the first created but the origin of creation. Revelation 3:14's 'beginning of creation' means source/ruler, not first creature (the same Christ through whom all was made, John 1:3; Col 1:16). Christ is both ἀρχή (beginning) and τέλος (end) - the Alpha and Omega (Rev 22:13). The 'rulers' (ἀρχαί) are cosmic powers, now subject to Christ. All authority structures find their origin and accountability in Him.

entries.shortDef: way, road, path, journey, manner of life
entries.title: Way: The Path of Life and Salvation
entries.summary: Ὁδός is way or road - both literal path and metaphorical way of life. Christ is THE Way to the Father. Early Christians were called followers of 'the Way.' God's ways are distinct from human ways. Walking in God's way means obedient living.
entries.classicalGreek: In classical Greek, ὁδός meant 'road, way, path' - literally, the route traveled. Metaphorically it extended to manner of life, conduct, and method. 'The way of' something meant its characteristic manner or the path leading to it.
entries.lxxBackground: The LXX uses ὁδός for דֶּרֶךְ (derek) - way, path, journey, conduct. God's way is perfect (Ps 18:30). The righteous walk in God's way (Ps 1:1, 6; Prov 2:20). Prepare the way of the Lord (Isa 40:3). Two ways: life and death (Jer 21:8). God's ways are higher than human ways (Isa 55:8-9).
entries.intertestamental: The two-ways teaching developed (life vs. death, light vs. darkness). The Qumran community walked in the way of truth. Wisdom literature emphasized the path of righteousness. The way to life was following Torah.
entries.ntUsage: 'I am the Way' (John 14:6). Prepare the way of the Lord (Matt 3:3; Mark 1:2-3). The narrow way leads to life (Matt 7:13-14). Early Christians called 'the Way' (Acts 9:2; 19:9, 23; 22:4; 24:14, 22). The way of salvation (Acts 16:17). The way of truth (2 Pet 2:2). A new and living way through Christ's flesh (Heb 10:20). The way of Cain (Jude 11).

keyPassages.greek: ἐγώ εἰμι ἡ ὁδὸς καὶ ἡ ἀλήθεια καὶ ἡ ζωή· οὐδεὶς ἔρχεται πρὸς τὸν πατέρα εἰ μὴ δι᾽ ἐμοῦ
keyPassages.significance: I am the way, the truth, and the life - exclusive access to the Father.

keyPassages.greek: τῆς ὁδοῦ ὄντας
keyPassages.significance: Those belonging to the Way - early Christian self-designation.

keyPassages.greek: ἣν ἐνεκαίνισεν ἡμῖν ὁδὸν πρόσφατον καὶ ζῶσαν διὰ τοῦ καταπετάσματος
keyPassages.significance: A new and living way through the veil - access through Christ's sacrifice.

entries.theologicalSignificance: Christ is not A way but THE Way - the exclusive path to the Father. This claim is central to Christian particularity. The early church's self-designation as 'the Way' emphasized Christianity as a manner of life, not merely belief system. Following Jesus means walking in His way - ethical obedience, not just theological assent. The two-ways teaching (Matt 7:13-14) maintains the biblical distinction between life and death paths. Christ opened a new way of access to God through His sacrifice. Christians are people of the Way.

entries.title: Humanity: Created, Fallen, and Renewed
entries.summary: Ἄνθρωπος is the fundamental NT term for human beings. Occurring over 550 times, it expresses biblical anthropology: humans created in God's image, fallen in Adam, and renewed in Christ the 'last Adam.' The term encompasses human nature, limitation, and dignity.
entries.classicalGreek: In classical Greek, ἄνθρωπος distinguished humans from gods (θεοί) and animals (θηρία). It emphasized human mortality and limitation - humans are 'mortals' compared to 'immortals.' Yet humans also held dignity as rational beings capable of virtue and civilization. The term could be used generally for 'mankind' or specifically for an individual 'person.'
entries.lxxBackground: The LXX uses ἄνθρωπος primarily for אָדָם (adam) - both the proper name Adam and the generic term for humanity. Genesis 1:26-27 establishes human dignity: made in God's image (εἰκών). Genesis 2:7 shows human constitution: formed from dust (χοῦς) and given the breath of life (πνοή). The Psalms explore human smallness before God (Ps 8:4) yet also human significance (Ps 8:5-6). Isaiah contrasts the frailty of human flesh with the enduring word of God (Isa 40:6-8).
entries.intertestamental: Second Temple literature developed the Adam/humanity theme. Sirach 17 expounds human creation in God's image. The Wisdom of Solomon explores human mortality and immortality. Apocalyptic texts use 'son of man' (υἱὸς ἀνθρώπου) for heavenly/eschatological figures (1 Enoch, 4 Ezra). Philo allegorized the two creation accounts as heavenly and earthly man.
entries.ntUsage: The Gospels contrast human limitation with divine power: 'with humans it is impossible, but with God all things are possible' (Matt 19:26). Jesus is both 'Son of Man' (ὁ υἱὸς τοῦ ἀνθρώπου) - his preferred self-designation - and the true human. Paul develops Adam Christology: through one man (ἄνθρωπος) sin entered (Rom 5:12), but Christ is the 'last Adam' (1 Cor 15:45) who reverses the curse. The 'old man' (παλαιὸς ἄνθρωπος) is crucified with Christ (Rom 6:6; Eph 4:22); the 'new man' (καινὸς ἄνθρωπος) is created in righteousness (Eph 4:24; Col 3:10). The 'inner man' (ἔσω ἄνθρωπος) is renewed daily (2 Cor 4:16). Humanity's destiny is conformity to Christ's image (Rom 8:29).

keyPassages.greek: δι' ἑνὸς ἀνθρώπου ἡ ἁμαρτία εἰς τὸν κόσμον εἰσῆλθεν
keyPassages.significance: Through one man sin entered the world - Adam's federal headship established. Paul's Adam-Christ typology grounds his soteriology.

keyPassages.greek: ἐπειδὴ γὰρ δι' ἀνθρώπου θάνατος, καὶ δι' ἀνθρώπου ἀνάστασις νεκρῶν
keyPassages.significance: Through a man came death, through a man came resurrection. What was lost through Adam is restored through Christ.

keyPassages.greek: καὶ ἐνδύσασθαι τὸν καινὸν ἄνθρωπον τὸν κατὰ θεὸν κτισθέντα
keyPassages.significance: Put on the new man created according to God - anthropology is renewed through regeneration.

entries.theologicalSignificance: Biblical anthropology stands against both ancient and modern reductionisms. Humans are neither divine (as in pantheism) nor mere animals (as in materialism). Created in God's image, humans possess inherent dignity, rationality, and moral responsibility. Yet the Fall corrupted human nature at every level. The gospel addresses this: Christ became true man (ἄνθρωπος) to save humans. Union with Christ restores the imago Dei. The 'new humanity' in Christ anticipates glorification. Understanding ἄνθρωπος rightly grounds ethics (human dignity), soteriology (human need), and eschatology (human destiny).

relatedWords.relationship: Adult male, husband (distinct from generic humanity)

entries.shortDef: brother, fellow believer, member of the Christian community
entries.title: Brotherhood: The Family of God
entries.summary: Ἀδελφός occurs over 340 times in the NT, becoming the characteristic term for fellow believers. While it literally means 'brother' (from the same womb), the early church adopted it to express their new spiritual kinship in Christ. Believers are brothers and sisters because they share one Father.
entries.classicalGreek: In classical Greek, ἀδελφός meant literally one born of the same mother (ἀ- 'same' + δελφύς 'womb'). It extended metaphorically to close friends, fellow citizens, or those sharing a common bond. The term expressed intimate connection and mutual obligation. Female counterpart: ἀδελφή (sister).
entries.lxxBackground: The LXX uses ἀδελφός for אָח (ach) - brother, kinsman, fellow Israelite. Blood relationships define covenant community: Abraham and Lot are 'brothers' (Gen 13:8). Fellow Israelites are 'brothers' (Deut 15:3, 7, 11). The term expresses covenant solidarity: 'Am I my brother's keeper?' (Gen 4:9). Israel's identity as family shapes ethics: laws protecting brothers from exploitation (Lev 25:35-46).
entries.intertestamental: In Second Temple Judaism, 'brother' designated fellow Jews as members of the covenant community. The Qumran community intensified this: members were 'brothers' in their strict fellowship. Philo spoke of Jews as brothers through common ancestry. Synagogue members addressed each other as brothers.
entries.ntUsage: Jesus redefines family: 'Whoever does the will of my Father in heaven is my brother and sister and mother' (Matt 12:50). Spiritual kinship supersedes biological. In Acts, ἀδελφοί becomes the standard address for the Christian community (Acts 1:15; 6:3; 15:1, etc.). Paul uses it constantly - Romans alone has over 20 occurrences. Christians are brothers because they share one Father (Rom 8:15-17), are adopted together (Eph 1:5), and are children of the same family (Gal 3:26). This brotherhood demands practical love: 'love one another with brotherly affection' (φιλαδελφία, Rom 12:10). The term creates obligation: care for 'the least of these brothers' (Matt 25:40); restore an erring brother gently (Gal 6:1); do not judge your brother (Rom 14:10).

keyPassages.greek: ὅστις γὰρ ἂν ποιήσῃ τὸ θέλημα τοῦ πατρός μου τοῦ ἐν οὐρανοῖς αὐτός μου ἀδελφὸς καὶ ἀδελφὴ καὶ μήτηρ ἐστίν
keyPassages.significance: Spiritual family defined by obedience to the Father, not blood relationship.

keyPassages.greek: εἰς τὸ εἶναι αὐτὸν πρωτότοκον ἐν πολλοῖς ἀδελφοῖς
keyPassages.significance: Christ is the firstborn among many brothers - believers share in His sonship.

keyPassages.greek: οὐκ ἐπαισχύνεται ἀδελφοὺς αὐτοὺς καλεῖν
keyPassages.significance: Christ is not ashamed to call us brothers - the incarnation establishes kinship.

entries.theologicalSignificance: The NT use of ἀδελφός expresses the radical new community created by the gospel. Believers from every nation, class, and background are genuine family - not metaphorically but really, through union with Christ and adoption by the Father. This brotherhood transcends all earthly divisions (Gal 3:28). It demands concrete expression: hospitality, mutual support, bearing one another's burdens, and genuine affection. The church is not an organization but a family. Christ's incarnation makes Him truly our brother (Heb 2:11-18), and through Him we become brothers to one another.

entries.shortDef: creation, creature, created thing, the act of creating
entries.title: Creation: God's Work and Groaning World
entries.summary: Κτίσις refers both to the act of creating and to the created order itself. The NT affirms God as Creator of all things, the creation's fall under Adam, and its future liberation. In Christ, believers are a 'new creation' - the firstfruits of cosmic renewal.
entries.classicalGreek: In classical Greek, κτίσις was rare, with κτίζω (to found, establish) being more common. It typically referred to the founding of cities or establishment of institutions. The concept of creation from nothing (creatio ex nihilo) was foreign to Greek philosophy, which generally assumed eternal matter shaped by a demiurge.
entries.lxxBackground: The LXX employs κτίζω and κτίσις for creation language, though not systematically. More common is ποιέω (make) for God's creative activity (Gen 1:1 LXX uses 'made' language). However, later texts use κτίσις: 'the beginning of God's ways for His works' (Prov 8:22); 'all creation' (Judith 9:12). The Wisdom of Solomon extensively uses creation theology: God created all things (Wis 1:14; 11:17).
entries.intertestamental: Second Temple texts develop creation theology. 2 Maccabees 7:28 explicitly states creation from nothing (ἐξ οὐκ ὄντων). Philo extensively treats creation, combining Genesis with Platonic ideas. The apocalyptic tradition anticipates new creation. The Qumran texts praise God as Creator and anticipate cosmic renewal.
entries.ntUsage: Mark 10:6 and 13:19 speak of creation's beginning (ἀρχή κτίσεως). Romans 1:20 argues God's attributes are visible in creation - leaving humanity without excuse. Romans 8:19-22 is the key passage: creation itself groans, subjected to futility through Adam's fall, awaiting liberation when God's children are glorified. Colossians 1:15-16 affirms Christ as the agent of creation: 'by Him all things were created' (ἐν αὐτῷ ἐκτίσθη τὰ πάντα). 2 Corinthians 5:17 and Galatians 6:15 declare believers a 'new creation' (καινὴ κτίσις) - regeneration as new creative act. Revelation anticipates the final new creation: new heaven and new earth (Rev 21:1).

keyPassages.greek: ἡ γὰρ ἀποκαραδοκία τῆς κτίσεως τὴν ἀποκάλυψιν τῶν υἱῶν τοῦ θεοῦ ἀπεκδέχεται
keyPassages.significance: Creation eagerly awaits the revealing of God's sons - cosmic redemption linked to human glorification.

keyPassages.greek: ὥστε εἴ τις ἐν Χριστῷ, καινὴ κτίσις
keyPassages.significance: If anyone is in Christ - new creation! Regeneration as new creative act paralleling Genesis.

keyPassages.greek: ἐν αὐτῷ ἐκτίσθη τὰ πάντα... τὰ πάντα δι' αὐτοῦ καὶ εἰς αὐτὸν ἔκτισται
keyPassages.significance: All things created in Him, through Him, and for Him - Christ is creation's origin, agent, and goal.

entries.theologicalSignificance: Κτίσις grounds Christian doctrine at every point. Creation theology affirms: (1) God's sovereignty - He made all things from nothing; (2) creation's goodness - made good, though now fallen; (3) cosmic scope of redemption - Christ saves not just souls but the entire created order; (4) human stewardship - as God's image-bearers, humans care for creation; (5) new creation in Christ - believers are the firstfruits of cosmic renewal. The groaning of creation (Rom 8) connects ecology and eschatology: the same God who will glorify His children will liberate His creation.

entries.shortDef: patient endurance, steadfastness, perseverance under trial
entries.title: Perseverance: The Endurance of Faith
entries.summary: Ὑπομονή is active, courageous endurance under trial - not passive resignation but steadfast perseverance. It is the virtue that holds fast to faith amid suffering, awaiting God's deliverance. Christ Himself is the model of patient endurance, and His Spirit enables believers to persevere to the end.
entries.classicalGreek: In classical Greek, ὑπομονή (from ὑπομένω, 'to remain under') meant bearing up under hardship, standing one's ground, or enduring courageously. The Stoics prized it as the virtue of maintaining tranquility amid adversity. It implied active resistance rather than passive submission - the soldier who holds his position under attack.
entries.lxxBackground: The LXX uses ὑπομονή and related terms for Hebrew words expressing waiting, hoping, and enduring. It translates קָוָה (qavah) - to wait, hope (Ps 25:21; 37:9). The righteous 'wait for the Lord' (Ps 27:14; 130:5). Job exemplifies patient endurance (ὑπομονή Ἰώβ - Job 14:19). Trust in God's faithfulness enables endurance through present suffering.
entries.intertestamental: In Second Temple literature, ὑπομονή became linked to martyrdom and eschatological hope. 4 Maccabees extensively praises the endurance of the martyrs who died rather than violate Torah. The apocalyptic texts encouraged endurance by revealing coming vindication. Qumran literature speaks of the period of waiting and endurance before the end.
entries.ntUsage: Jesus calls for endurance: 'the one who endures to the end will be saved' (Matt 24:13). Romans 5:3-4 traces the progression: suffering produces endurance, endurance produces character, character produces hope. Romans 15:4-5 identifies God as the source of ὑπομονή. Hebrews 12:1-2 urges running with endurance (ὑπομονῆς), looking to Jesus who 'endured' (ὑπέμεινεν) the cross. James 1:2-4 explains that trials produce endurance, and endurance must 'complete its work.' James 5:11 points to Job's patience and the Lord's outcome. Revelation repeatedly calls for 'the endurance of the saints' (Rev 13:10; 14:12). Patient endurance characterizes the Christian life between Christ's advents.

keyPassages.greek: ἡ θλῖψις ὑπομονὴν κατεργάζεται, ἡ δὲ ὑπομονὴ δοκιμήν, ἡ δὲ δοκιμὴ ἐλπίδα
keyPassages.significance: Suffering works endurance, endurance works character, character works hope - the progressive work of grace.

keyPassages.greek: δι᾽ ὑπομονῆς τρέχωμεν τὸν προκείμενον ἡμῖν ἀγῶνα
keyPassages.significance: Run with endurance the race set before us - the Christian life as athletic contest requiring stamina.

keyPassages.greek: Ὧδε ἡ ὑπομονὴ τῶν ἁγίων ἐστίν
keyPassages.significance: Here is the endurance of the saints - perseverance in the face of beastly opposition.

entries.theologicalSignificance: Ὑπομονή is not stoic resignation but active faith that holds fast to God's promises amid trial. It differs from μακροθυμία (patience toward persons) as endurance under circumstances and suffering. Biblical endurance is: (1) God-given - He is 'the God of endurance' (Rom 15:5); (2) Christ-modeled - Jesus endured the cross (Heb 12:2); (3) Spirit-enabled - produced by divine power (Col 1:11); (4) eschatologically-oriented - enduring for the coming reward; (5) character-forming - trials produce proven character. The perseverance of the saints is both divine gift and human responsibility.

relatedWords.relationship: Verb: to remain under, endure (Matt 10:22; Heb 12:2)
Patience, long-suffering (toward persons rather than circumstances)

entries.title: New: The Qualitative Newness of the Gospel
entries.summary: Καινός denotes qualitative newness - something fresh, unprecedented, or renewed in kind. Distinguished from νέος (new in time), καινός expresses the gospel's transformative power: new covenant, new commandment, new creation, new humanity. In Christ, all things become καινός.
entries.classicalGreek: In classical Greek, καινός meant 'new' in the sense of fresh, novel, or unprecedented - what has not existed before in this form. It contrasted with παλαιός (old, ancient). The term could carry positive (innovative, fresh) or negative (strange, untested) connotations. It differed from νέος, which emphasized newness in time (young, recent).
entries.lxxBackground: The LXX uses καινός for Hebrew חָדָשׁ (chadash) - new, fresh. God does 'new things' (Isa 42:9; 43:19). A 'new heart and new spirit' are promised (Ezek 18:31; 36:26). The 'new covenant' prophecy (Jer 31:31) is foundational. 'New heavens and new earth' anticipate cosmic renewal (Isa 65:17; 66:22). The 'new song' celebrates God's new acts of salvation (Ps 96:1; 98:1).
entries.intertestamental: Apocalyptic texts developed the new creation theme. Jubilees and 1 Enoch anticipate cosmic renewal. The Qumran community saw themselves as the new Israel with renewed covenant. Jewish expectation held that the messianic age would bring qualitatively new realities, not merely restoration of the old.
entries.ntUsage: Jesus brings the 'new covenant' in His blood (Luke 22:20; 1 Cor 11:25). He gives a 'new commandment' - love one another (John 13:34). New wine requires new wineskins (Mark 2:22) - the gospel cannot be contained in old forms. Paul proclaims the 'new creation' (2 Cor 5:17; Gal 6:15) and the 'new man/humanity' (Eph 2:15; 4:24; Col 3:10). Hebrews contrasts old and new covenants (Heb 8:8, 13; 9:15; 12:24). Revelation culminates in 'new heaven and new earth' (Rev 21:1), 'new Jerusalem' (Rev 21:2), and God making 'all things new' (Rev 21:5). The new name given to believers (Rev 2:17; 3:12) signifies transformed identity.

keyPassages.greek: εἴ τις ἐν Χριστῷ, καινὴ κτίσις· τὰ ἀρχαῖα παρῆλθεν, ἰδοὺ γέγονεν καινά
keyPassages.significance: If anyone in Christ - new creation! The old passed away, behold new things have come.

keyPassages.greek: ἐν τῷ λέγειν καινὴν πεπαλαίωκεν τὴν πρώτην
keyPassages.significance: By saying 'new' He has made the first old - the new covenant supersedes the old.

keyPassages.greek: Ἰδοὺ καινὰ ποιῶ πάντα
keyPassages.significance: Behold, I make all things new - eschatological renewal of all creation.

entries.theologicalSignificance: Καινός expresses the heart of biblical eschatology: God is doing something genuinely new, not merely repairing the old. The new covenant fulfills and surpasses the old (Heb 8). The new creation transforms rather than merely restores Eden. The 'already/not yet' tension applies: believers are already new creation in Christ, yet await the consummation when all things are made new. This qualitative newness means Christianity is not mere religion or moral improvement but participation in the new age inaugurated by Christ's resurrection. The imperative follows the indicative: those who are new creation must 'put on the new man' (Eph 4:24).

relatedWords.relationship: New in time, young, recent (distinguished from qualitative newness)
To renew, make new again (2 Cor 4:16; Col 3:10)

entries.shortDef: time, period of time, duration, age
entries.title: Time: Duration and God's Patience
entries.summary: Χρόνος denotes time as duration or extent - a period measured by succession of moments. Distinguished from καιρός (opportune moment), χρόνος expresses God's sovereign control over times and seasons, His patience that extends time for repentance, and the history within which salvation unfolds.
entries.classicalGreek: In classical Greek, χρόνος was the general term for time - both time as a whole and specific periods or durations. It could be personified as Chronos, the god of time. Aristotle defined time as 'the measure of motion.' The term expressed the linear succession of past, present, and future. Greek thought often viewed time cyclically, in contrast to the linear biblical view.
entries.lxxBackground: The LXX uses χρόνος for various Hebrew time-words, especially עֵת (et) and יוֹם (yom) when referring to extended periods. 'Times and seasons' (χρόνους καὶ καιρούς) are in God's hand (Dan 2:21). God has appointed times for His purposes (Eccl 3:1-8). The duration of suffering and the timing of deliverance are His to determine (Gen 29:14; Judg 18:31).
entries.intertestamental: Apocalyptic literature divided history into epochs (χρόνοι) leading to the end. Daniel's time prophecies (Dan 7:25; 12:7) influenced later calculations. The Qumran community believed they lived in the last times. 4 Ezra puzzles over the length of time before the end.
entries.ntUsage: Jesus declares it is not for disciples to know 'times or seasons' (χρόνους ἢ καιρούς) the Father has set (Acts 1:7). God's patience extends time for repentance (2 Pet 3:9) - what seems like delay is divine forbearance. The 'time of ignorance' God overlooked, but now commands repentance (Acts 17:30). Paul speaks of 'the fullness of time' (Gal 4:4) when God sent His Son - all history prepared for that moment. The 'times of the Gentiles' must be fulfilled (Luke 21:24). Revelation speaks of time ending: 'there should be delay no longer' (Rev 10:6). History moves toward its appointed consummation.

keyPassages.greek: οὐχ ὑμῶν ἐστιν γνῶναι χρόνους ἢ καιρούς
keyPassages.significance: Not for you to know times or seasons - God sovereignly controls historical epochs.

keyPassages.greek: ὅτε δὲ ἦλθεν τὸ πλήρωμα τοῦ χρόνου
keyPassages.significance: When the fullness of time came - Christ's incarnation at the divinely appointed moment.

keyPassages.greek: μακροθυμεῖ εἰς ὑμᾶς, μὴ βουλόμενός τινας ἀπολέσθαι
keyPassages.significance: The Lord is patient - apparent delay is salvation opportunity.

entries.theologicalSignificance: Χρόνος teaches that time itself belongs to God. He created it, governs it, and will consummate it. Biblical faith is historical: salvation happens in time, not escape from time. Yet time moves toward its goal - it is not endless repetition but purposeful duration. God's patience in extending time demonstrates His desire for all to repent. The 'fullness of time' (Gal 4:4) shows divine planning across all human history. Understanding χρόνος prevents both despair (God controls time) and presumption (we must use time wisely). The distinction from καιρός helps: χρόνος is the ongoing duration; καιρός is the decisive moment within it.

relatedWords.relationship: Opportune time, decisive moment (qualitative rather than quantitative)

entries.shortDef: opportune time, appointed season, critical moment
entries.title: The Decisive Moment: God's Appointed Time
entries.summary: Καιρός denotes the right, opportune, or appointed time - the critical moment for decision and action. Distinguished from χρόνος (duration), καιρός expresses God's appointed times for salvation history. Jesus came at the right καιρός, and believers must recognize and respond to their καιρός of opportunity.
entries.classicalGreek: In classical Greek, καιρός meant the right, proper, or opportune moment - the critical point when action would be effective. It was the 'due measure' in all things. Hippocrates spoke of καιρός in medicine - the precise moment for treatment. The term implied opportunity that could be seized or missed. It was sometimes personified as a fleeting deity to be grasped by the forelock.
entries.lxxBackground: The LXX uses καιρός for Hebrew עֵת (et) and מוֹעֵד (moed) - appointed times and seasons. 'For everything there is a season, and a time (καιρός) for every matter' (Eccl 3:1). God has made everything 'beautiful in its time' (Eccl 3:11). The festivals are 'appointed times' (Lev 23:2, 4). Daniel speaks of 'time, times, and half a time' (Dan 7:25). The καιρός of salvation is coming (Isa 49:8).
entries.intertestamental: Apocalyptic texts anticipated the decisive καιρός of the end. The 'times and seasons' were mysteriously determined by God. The Qumran community believed they lived at the decisive turning point. 4 Ezra wrestles with when the end-time καιρός would arrive.
entries.ntUsage: Jesus announces: 'The καιρός is fulfilled' (Mark 1:15) - the decisive moment has arrived. He weeps over Jerusalem for not recognizing 'the time (καιρός) of your visitation' (Luke 19:44). The present is 'the acceptable time' (καιρός εὐπρόσδεκτος), 'the day of salvation' (2 Cor 6:2). Believers must understand 'the present time' (καιρός, Rom 13:11) and 'redeem the time' (Eph 5:16; Col 4:5). Suffering is 'for a little while' before glory (1 Pet 1:6). The 'times of the Gentiles' (Luke 21:24) and 'times of refreshing' (Acts 3:19) mark salvation history's epochs. God will reveal Christ 'at the proper time' (1 Tim 6:15).

keyPassages.greek: πεπλήρωται ὁ καιρὸς καὶ ἤγγικεν ἡ βασιλεία τοῦ θεοῦ
keyPassages.significance: The time is fulfilled and the kingdom has come near - the decisive moment of salvation history has arrived.

keyPassages.greek: οὐκ ἔγνως τὸν καιρὸν τῆς ἐπισκοπῆς σου
keyPassages.significance: You did not recognize the time of your visitation - missing the decisive moment brings judgment.

keyPassages.greek: ἐξαγοραζόμενοι τὸν καιρόν
keyPassages.significance: Redeeming the time - making the most of every opportunity in evil days.

entries.theologicalSignificance: Καιρός expresses the biblical view that time has meaning - not all moments are equal. God acts at the right time (Gal 4:4), and humans must respond at the right time. The incarnation, crucifixion, and resurrection are the central καιρός of history. Missing one's καιρός brings tragedy (Luke 19:44). The present is always a καιρός of decision - 'now is the acceptable time' (2 Cor 6:2). Believers live between Christ's first and second coming, called to recognize and respond to their καιρός. This creates urgency: opportunities for witness, service, and obedience will not last forever. 'Redeeming the time' (Eph 5:16) means seizing present opportunities with wisdom.

relatedWords.relationship: Time as duration (quantitative rather than qualitative)
Hour, specific time point (often in John for Jesus' decisive 'hour')

entries.title: Apocalypse: The Unveiling of Divine Mystery
entries.summary: Ἀποκάλυψις means 'unveiling' or 'uncovering' - the disclosure of what was previously hidden. It names the final book of Scripture ('Revelation') and expresses the Christian conviction that God has revealed Himself and His purposes in Christ. The eschatological 'apocalypse' of Christ is both past (His first coming) and future (His return).
entries.classicalGreek: In classical Greek, ἀποκάλυψις (from ἀπό 'from' + καλύπτω 'to cover') simply meant 'uncovering' or 'disclosure.' It was used literally for removing a covering and metaphorically for revealing secrets or making known what was hidden. The term had no special religious significance in pagan Greek.
entries.lxxBackground: The LXX uses ἀποκαλύπτω occasionally for גָּלָה (galah) - to uncover, reveal. God reveals secrets (Dan 2:19, 22, 28-29). The 'arm of the Lord' is revealed (Isa 52:10; 53:1). Divine revelation comes through prophets: 'The Lord GOD does nothing without revealing His secret to His servants the prophets' (Amos 3:7). The apocalyptic tradition (Daniel, Ezekiel) provides visions of heavenly realities and future events.
entries.intertestamental: The apocalyptic literature (1 Enoch, 4 Ezra, 2 Baruch, etc.) developed the 'revelation' concept extensively. Heavenly secrets are revealed to chosen seers through visions and angelic interpreters. Hidden wisdom about cosmic battles, future judgment, and coming salvation is 'unveiled' to the faithful. This genre gave rise to the term 'apocalyptic' - literature revealing end-time mysteries.
entries.ntUsage: Revelation 1:1 opens: 'The revelation (ἀποκάλυψις) of Jesus Christ' - both revelation from Christ and about Christ. Paul speaks of 'revelation' as the mode of receiving the gospel (Gal 1:12) and understanding mystery (Eph 3:3). The coming of Christ is His 'revelation' (ἀποκάλυψις, 1 Cor 1:7; 2 Thess 1:7; 1 Pet 1:7, 13). Present suffering prepares for 'the glory about to be revealed' (Rom 8:18). The 'sons of God' await their 'revelation' (Rom 8:19). Divine wrath is 'revealed' (Rom 1:18) as is righteousness (Rom 1:17). God reveals spiritual truth to believers (Matt 11:25; 1 Cor 2:10; Phil 3:15).

keyPassages.greek: Ἀποκάλυψις Ἰησοῦ Χριστοῦ
keyPassages.significance: The revelation of Jesus Christ - unveiling of divine purposes centering on Christ.

keyPassages.greek: τὴν μέλλουσαν δόξαν ἀποκαλυφθῆναι εἰς ἡμᾶς... τὴν ἀποκάλυψιν τῶν υἱῶν τοῦ θεοῦ
keyPassages.significance: The glory about to be revealed, the revelation of the sons of God - eschatological unveiling.

keyPassages.greek: δι᾽ ἀποκαλύψεως Ἰησοῦ Χριστοῦ
keyPassages.significance: Through revelation of Jesus Christ - Paul's gospel came by divine disclosure, not human teaching.

entries.theologicalSignificance: Ἀποκάλυψις grounds Christian epistemology: we know God because He has revealed Himself. Natural theology has limits (Rom 1:19-20); saving knowledge comes through special revelation in Christ and Scripture. The term encompasses: (1) God's past revelation in Christ - the incarnation unveiled divine glory (John 1:14); (2) ongoing revelation through Scripture and Spirit to the church; (3) future revelation at Christ's return - the final 'apocalypse.' Revelation involves both disclosure and response - what God unveils must be received by faith. The book of Revelation 'unveils' not coded predictions but Christ's victory and the church's hope amid persecution. All history moves toward the full revelation of God's glory in Christ.

relatedWords.relationship: Verb: to reveal, uncover, disclose (Matt 11:25; Rom 1:17-18)
To make manifest, show clearly (related but emphasizing visibility)
Mystery - what is revealed was previously hidden (Rom 16:25; Eph 3:3)

entries.title: Witness: The Testimony That Creates Faith
entries.summary: Μαρτυρία is testimony or witness - the evidence given to establish truth. In the NT, it becomes central to gospel proclamation: the apostles are witnesses to Christ's resurrection, and believers bear witness to what God has done. The term develops into 'martyrdom' - witness unto death.
entries.classicalGreek: In classical Greek, μαρτυρία was legal terminology - the testimony given in court to establish facts. A μάρτυς (witness) was one who could testify to what they had seen or known firsthand. The testimony's validity depended on the witness's reliability and direct knowledge.
entries.lxxBackground: The LXX uses μαρτυρία and related words for Hebrew עֵד (ed) and עֵדוּת (edut) - witness, testimony. God's law is His 'testimony' (Ps 19:7; 119:88). The tabernacle is the 'tent of testimony' (Num 1:50). False witness is prohibited (Ex 20:16; Deut 19:16-18). God Himself is witness (Gen 31:50; Jer 29:23).
entries.intertestamental: In Second Temple Judaism, the 'two or three witnesses' requirement (Deut 19:15) was carefully applied. The Qumran community regulated testimony in their courts. Martyrdom theology developed - faithful witnesses to Torah sometimes died rather than compromise, becoming 'martyrs' in the later sense.
entries.ntUsage: John's Gospel emphasizes witness: John the Baptist 'came for testimony' (John 1:7); Jesus' works bear witness (John 5:36); the Father witnesses (John 5:37); Scripture witnesses (John 5:39). The apostles are 'witnesses' to the resurrection (Acts 1:8, 22; 2:32; 3:15). 1 John speaks of God's testimony concerning His Son (1 John 5:9-11). Revelation calls Jesus 'the faithful witness' (Rev 1:5; 3:14). The two witnesses prophesy (Rev 11:3). By the second century, μάρτυς came to mean specifically one who died for the faith - a 'martyr.'

keyPassages.greek: οὗτος ἦλθεν εἰς μαρτυρίαν, ἵνα μαρτυρήσῃ περὶ τοῦ φωτός
keyPassages.significance: John came for testimony, to bear witness about the Light - witness creates faith.

keyPassages.greek: ἔσεσθέ μου μάρτυρες
keyPassages.significance: You will be my witnesses - the apostolic mission defined as testimony.

keyPassages.greek: ἡ μαρτυρία τοῦ θεοῦ μείζων ἐστίν
keyPassages.significance: God's testimony is greater - divine witness establishes truth about the Son.

entries.theologicalSignificance: Μαρτυρία grounds Christian epistemology in testimony. Faith comes through witness - we believe because of apostolic testimony to Christ (John 17:20; 1 John 1:1-3). This testimony is not mere opinion but eyewitness evidence of historical events, supremely the resurrection. God Himself bears witness through the Spirit (1 John 5:6-8). The church's mission is fundamentally μαρτυρία - bearing witness to Christ. When witness requires death, the testimony becomes most powerful. The 'blood of the martyrs is the seed of the church' because faithful witness unto death demonstrates conviction's reality.

entries.title: Consolation: The Ministry of Encouragement
entries.summary: Παράκλησις encompasses encouragement, exhortation, and comfort - the full ministry of coming alongside others. It connects to παράκλητος (Paraclete), the Holy Spirit's title. God is 'the God of all comfort,' and believers share in this ministry of consolation.
entries.classicalGreek: In classical Greek, παράκλησις meant a calling to one's side, hence summoning (especially for help), exhortation, or encouragement. It could denote the act of appealing, urging, or encouraging. The word carried connotations of strengthening someone for a task or comforting in distress.
entries.lxxBackground: The LXX uses παράκλησις and παρακαλέω for Hebrew נחם (nacham) - to comfort, console. Isaiah's 'Comfort, comfort my people' (Isa 40:1) uses παρακαλεῖτε. The messianic hope includes the 'consolation of Israel' (Isa 57:18; 66:11). God comforts His people as a mother comforts her child (Isa 66:13).
entries.intertestamental: Second Temple Judaism anticipated messianic consolation. Simeon waited for 'the consolation of Israel' (Luke 2:25 - παράκλησιν τοῦ Ἰσραήλ). The rabbis spoke of the 'Comforter' (Menachem) as a messianic title. Comfort in suffering was a major theme given persecution and exile.
entries.ntUsage: 2 Corinthians 1:3-7 is the key passage: God is 'the Father of mercies and God of all comfort (παρακλήσεως), who comforts us in all our affliction.' Believers then comfort others with the comfort they received. Romans 15:4-5 says Scripture gives παράκλησις. Acts uses the term for prophetic/apostolic encouragement (Acts 4:36 - Barnabas means 'son of encouragement'; Acts 13:15; 15:31). Hebrews 6:18 speaks of 'strong encouragement.' The ministry of παράκλησις includes exhortation to faithfulness (Heb 12:5; 13:22) as well as comfort in sorrow.

keyPassages.greek: ὁ θεὸς πάσης παρακλήσεως, ὁ παρακαλῶν ἡμᾶς ἐπὶ πάσῃ τῇ θλίψει ἡμῶν
keyPassages.significance: God of all comfort who comforts us in all affliction - divine comfort as source and model.

keyPassages.greek: προσδεχόμενος παράκλησιν τοῦ Ἰσραήλ
keyPassages.significance: Waiting for the consolation of Israel - messianic hope as comfort fulfilled in Christ.

keyPassages.greek: Βαρναβᾶς, ὅ ἐστιν μεθερμηνευόμενον υἱὸς παρακλήσεως
keyPassages.significance: Son of encouragement - character defined by ministry of comfort/exhortation.

entries.theologicalSignificance: Παράκλησις reveals a God who draws near to comfort His afflicted people. The messianic age is characterized by divine consolation (Isa 40:1; Luke 2:25). The Holy Spirit as Παράκλητος (John 14-16) embodies this ministry - coming alongside to strengthen, guide, and comfort. Believers receive comfort not as an end but as equipment for ministry: 'comfort others with the comfort we have received' (2 Cor 1:4). The word's range - from tender consolation to urgent exhortation - shows that true encouragement sometimes comforts the afflicted and sometimes afflicts the comfortable. Barnabas as 'son of παράκλησις' models this ministry.

relatedWords.relationship: To call alongside, comfort, exhort, encourage (2 Cor 1:4)
Advocate, Helper, Comforter - title of the Holy Spirit (John 14:16, 26)
Comfort, consolation (more tender than παράκλησις) (1 Cor 14:3)

entries.title: Peace: Shalom in Greek Dress
entries.summary: Εἰρήνη translates Hebrew שָׁלוֹם (shalom), encompassing far more than absence of conflict. It means wholeness, well-being, right relationships, and flourishing. Christ is 'our peace' who reconciles enemies to God and to each other, creating one new humanity.
entries.classicalGreek: In classical Greek, εἰρήνη primarily meant the opposite of war - a state of peace between nations or cessation of hostilities. It could extend to public order, tranquility, and harmonious relationships. The Greek concept was largely negative - the absence of conflict rather than positive flourishing.
entries.lxxBackground: The LXX uses εἰρήνη to translate שָׁלוֹם (shalom), dramatically expanding the word's meaning. Hebrew shalom is positive wholeness: health, prosperity, security, good relationships, and covenant blessing. 'Peace' is how Israelites greeted each other, blessed departing guests, and described the messianic age. The Aaronic benediction concludes with peace (Num 6:26). The messianic prince brings peace (Isa 9:6-7). 'Peace, peace to the far and near' (Isa 57:19).
entries.intertestamental: Second Temple Judaism longed for the peace of the messianic age. The Qumran community anticipated eschatological peace after the final war. Rabbinic literature praised peace as the vessel containing all blessings. 'Great is peace, for all blessings are contained in it.'
entries.ntUsage: The angels announce 'peace on earth' at Christ's birth (Luke 2:14). Jesus says 'Peace I leave with you' (John 14:27) and greets disciples with 'Peace be with you' (John 20:19, 21). Paul's letters open with 'grace and peace.' Romans 5:1 declares 'we have peace with God through our Lord Jesus Christ' - reconciliation accomplished. Ephesians 2:14-17 proclaims Christ 'is our peace' who broke down the dividing wall, reconciling Jew and Gentile, creating one new humanity, preaching 'peace to you who were far off and peace to those who were near.' The fruit of the Spirit includes peace (Gal 5:22). Believers are to 'pursue peace' (Heb 12:14; Rom 14:19) and 'live in peace' (2 Cor 13:11).

keyPassages.greek: αὐτὸς γάρ ἐστιν ἡ εἰρήνη ἡμῶν
keyPassages.significance: He Himself is our peace - Christ doesn't just bring peace, He IS peace, embodying reconciliation.

keyPassages.greek: εἰρήνην ἔχομεν πρὸς τὸν θεόν
keyPassages.significance: We have peace with God - justification ends the state of enmity, establishing reconciled relationship.

keyPassages.greek: εἰρήνην ἀφίημι ὑμῖν, εἰρήνην τὴν ἐμὴν δίδωμι ὑμῖν
keyPassages.significance: My peace I give you - Christ's unique peace, different from the world's, based on His finished work.

entries.theologicalSignificance: Εἰρήνη in the NT carries the full freight of Hebrew shalom. It is not mere tranquility but comprehensive well-being rooted in right relationship with God. Sin creates enmity with God (Rom 5:10; 8:7); the gospel announces peace through Christ's blood (Col 1:20). This vertical peace with God (Rom 5:1) creates horizontal peace among believers (Eph 4:3) and even with enemies where possible (Rom 12:18). The 'God of peace' (Rom 15:33; 16:20; Phil 4:9) will ultimately crush Satan and establish eternal shalom. Until then, Christ's peace guards believers' hearts (Phil 4:7) amid a hostile world.

relatedWords.relationship: To be at peace, live in peace (Mark 9:50; Rom 12:18)

entries.title: The End: Goal, Fulfillment, and Consummation
entries.summary: Τέλος means both 'end' (termination) and 'goal' (purpose/completion). This dual meaning is theologically rich: history moves toward its telos; Christ is the telos of the law; the telos of faith is salvation. The end is not mere cessation but fulfillment of purpose.
entries.classicalGreek: In classical Greek, τέλος had a range of meanings: end or termination; goal or purpose; completion or fulfillment; the highest point or perfection; tax or toll (as completion of obligation). Aristotle used it philosophically for the final cause - the purpose for which something exists. The τέλος of an acorn is an oak tree.
entries.lxxBackground: The LXX uses τέλος for various Hebrew terms, especially קֵץ (qets - end) and תַּכְלִית (taklit - end, purpose). 'The end of the matter' (Eccl 12:13). Daniel speaks of 'the time of the end' (Dan 8:17; 11:35, 40; 12:4, 9). The Psalms use τέλος in superscriptions (Ps 4:1; 5:1, etc.) - possibly meaning 'for the choir director' or 'to the end.'
entries.intertestamental: Apocalyptic literature developed 'end-time' (eschaton) theology extensively. 4 Ezra, 2 Baruch, and other texts describe 'the end' when God intervenes decisively. The Qumran community believed they lived in the 'last days' before the end.
entries.ntUsage: Jesus speaks of 'the end' (τέλος) of the age (Matt 24:6, 14). Paul says 'the end' comes when Christ delivers the kingdom to the Father (1 Cor 15:24). Romans 6:21-22 contrasts outcomes: 'the end of those things is death' versus 'the outcome is eternal life.' Most significantly, Romans 10:4 declares 'Christ is the τέλος of the law' - meaning both that Christ ends the law's condemning function and that Christ is the goal toward which the law always pointed. 1 Peter 1:9 speaks of 'the τέλος of your faith - the salvation of your souls.' James 5:11 points to 'the τέλος of the Lord' in Job's story - God's ultimate purpose. 1 Timothy 1:5 says 'the τέλος of the commandment is love.'

keyPassages.greek: τέλος γὰρ νόμου Χριστὸς εἰς δικαιοσύνην παντὶ τῷ πιστεύοντι
keyPassages.significance: Christ is the telos of the law - both its termination and its fulfillment/goal.

keyPassages.greek: κομιζόμενοι τὸ τέλος τῆς πίστεως ὑμῶν σωτηρίαν ψυχῶν
keyPassages.significance: Obtaining the outcome/goal of faith - salvation as faith's intended destination.

keyPassages.greek: εἶτα τὸ τέλος, ὅταν παραδιδῷ τὴν βασιλείαν τῷ θεῷ
keyPassages.significance: Then the end - eschatological consummation when Christ delivers the kingdom.

entries.theologicalSignificance: Τέλος teaches that history has purpose and direction. God is working toward a goal - not mere termination but glorious completion. Christ as the τέλος of the law (Rom 10:4) means the law finds its fulfillment in Him; those in Christ have reached what the law aimed at. Eschatologically, 'the end' is not destruction but consummation - the completion of God's redemptive purposes. The τέλος of faith is salvation (1 Pet 1:9) - faith has a destination. This gives Christian hope its teleological character: we are heading somewhere, toward the telos God has appointed. 'He who began a good work will bring it to completion' (Phil 1:6).

relatedWords.relationship: To complete, finish, accomplish (John 19:30 'It is finished')
To make perfect, complete, bring to goal (Heb 2:10; 5:9)

entries.title: Wisdom: Christ the Power and Wisdom of God
entries.summary: Σοφία is wisdom - not merely intellectual knowledge but practical insight for living well. In the OT, personified Wisdom participates in creation. Paul radically declares Christ to be 'the wisdom of God' - God's wise plan that appears foolish to the world but accomplishes salvation.
entries.classicalGreek: In classical Greek, σοφία meant skill or expertise in any craft, then broadened to wisdom in general - sound judgment, practical intelligence, and philosophical insight. The σοφός (wise person) possessed knowledge and the ability to apply it well. Greek philosophy sought σοφία as the highest pursuit (philo-sophia = love of wisdom).
entries.lxxBackground: The LXX uses σοφία for חָכְמָה (chokmah) - wisdom. Proverbs, Job, and Ecclesiastes explore wisdom extensively. Wisdom is 'the beginning of knowledge' (Prov 1:7); 'better than gold' (Prov 16:16). Most striking is personified Wisdom in Proverbs 8: present at creation (8:22-31), calling people to life (8:1-21). The Wisdom of Solomon develops this: Wisdom as divine emanation, the 'fashioner of all things' (Wis 7:22), who delivers God's people (Wis 10).
entries.intertestamental: Second Temple Judaism highly developed Wisdom theology. Sirach (Ecclesiasticus) identifies Wisdom with Torah (Sir 24). The Wisdom of Solomon presents Wisdom as cosmic mediator. Some scholars see the roots of NT Christology here - divine Wisdom providing a category for understanding Christ's pre-existence and role in creation.
entries.ntUsage: Paul dramatically proclaims 'Christ the power of God and the wisdom of God' (1 Cor 1:24). The cross appears foolish but is God's wisdom (1 Cor 1:18-25). In Christ 'are hidden all the treasures of wisdom and knowledge' (Col 2:3). James distinguishes earthly wisdom from 'wisdom from above' (Jas 3:13-17). Revelation praises the Lamb: 'Worthy is the Lamb... to receive... wisdom' (Rev 5:12). Jesus as a child 'grew in wisdom' (Luke 2:52) and astounded hearers with wisdom (Matt 13:54). Yet Jesus is 'greater than Solomon' (Matt 12:42). Stephen was 'full of wisdom' (Acts 6:3, 10). Paul prays believers receive 'a spirit of wisdom' (Eph 1:17).

keyPassages.greek: Χριστὸν θεοῦ δύναμιν καὶ θεοῦ σοφίαν
keyPassages.significance: Christ is God's power and God's wisdom - the crucified Messiah embodies divine wisdom.

keyPassages.greek: ἐν ᾧ εἰσιν πάντες οἱ θησαυροὶ τῆς σοφίας καὶ γνώσεως ἀπόκρυφοι
keyPassages.significance: In Christ all treasures of wisdom are hidden - no need to seek wisdom elsewhere.

keyPassages.greek: ἡ δὲ ἄνωθεν σοφία πρῶτον μὲν ἁγνή ἐστιν
keyPassages.significance: Wisdom from above is first pure - divine wisdom has distinctive character.

entries.theologicalSignificance: Σοφία in the NT reaches its apex in Christology. The Wisdom tradition of Proverbs 8, which personified Wisdom as God's agent in creation, finds its fulfillment in Christ. He is not merely wise but is Wisdom itself (1 Cor 1:24, 30). The cross, which appears foolish to human wisdom, is actually God's supremely wise plan for salvation. This inverts worldly values: God's 'foolishness' is wiser than human wisdom (1 Cor 1:25). Christians receive wisdom through Christ and the Spirit (1 Cor 2:6-16; Eph 1:17; Col 1:9). True wisdom manifests in godly living (Jas 3:13-17), not merely intellectual attainment.

relatedWords.relationship: To make wise (2 Tim 3:15); to devise cleverly (2 Pet 1:16)

entries.title: Glory: The Radiant Weight of Divine Presence
entries.summary: Δόξα means glory - the visible manifestation of God's excellence, the radiant splendor of His presence. The Hebrew כָּבוֹד (kabod) means 'weight' or 'heaviness' - God's glory is His substantial, impressive reality. Christ reveals the Father's glory; believers are being transformed into His glorious image.
entries.classicalGreek: In classical Greek, δόξα meant opinion, reputation, or the honor/glory that comes from others' estimation. It was the good reputation or fame that a person enjoyed. This is quite different from the OT sense of divine radiance, which the NT adopts through the LXX.
entries.lxxBackground: The LXX uses δόξα to translate כָּבוֹד (kabod) - glory, honor, weight. God's glory is His manifest presence: the cloud filling the tabernacle (Ex 40:34-35), the glory departing the temple (Ezek 10-11), the glory returning (Ezek 43:1-5). 'The whole earth is full of His glory' (Isa 6:3). God will not give His glory to another (Isa 42:8; 48:11). The glory of the LORD will be revealed (Isa 40:5).
entries.intertestamental: Second Temple Judaism developed glory theology carefully, especially regarding theophanies. The Targums speak of the 'glory of the Shekinah.' Apocalyptic visions describe heavenly glory (1 Enoch, 4 Ezra). The Qumran Hodayot praise God's glory. Glory becomes almost a circumlocution for God's presence.
entries.ntUsage: The shepherds see 'the glory of the Lord' (Luke 2:9). Jesus' transfiguration reveals His glory (Luke 9:32). John declares: 'We have seen his glory' (John 1:14) - the incarnate Word manifests divine glory. Jesus' miracles are 'signs' revealing glory (John 2:11). The cross is paradoxically Jesus' glorification (John 12:23; 13:31; 17:1). Paul speaks of 'the glory of God in the face of Jesus Christ' (2 Cor 4:6). Believers are being transformed 'from glory to glory' (2 Cor 3:18). The ultimate hope is sharing Christ's glory (Rom 8:17-18; Col 3:4). Doxologies praise God's glory forever (Rom 11:36; 16:27; Eph 3:21; Phil 4:20).

keyPassages.greek: ἐθεασάμεθα τὴν δόξαν αὐτοῦ, δόξαν ὡς μονογενοῦς παρὰ πατρός
keyPassages.significance: We have seen His glory - the incarnation makes divine glory visible in human flesh.

keyPassages.greek: τὴν αὐτὴν εἰκόνα μεταμορφούμεθα ἀπὸ δόξης εἰς δόξαν
keyPassages.significance: Being transformed from glory to glory - sanctification as progressive glorification.

keyPassages.greek: οὐκ ἄξια τὰ παθήματα τοῦ νῦν καιροῦ πρὸς τὴν μέλλουσαν δόξαν ἀποκαλυφθῆναι
keyPassages.significance: Present sufferings not worth comparing with coming glory - eschatological hope.

entries.theologicalSignificance: Δόξα is perhaps the most God-centered word in Scripture. All things exist for God's glory (Rom 11:36; 1 Cor 10:31). The goal of salvation is 'the praise of His glory' (Eph 1:6, 12, 14). Sin is falling short of God's glory (Rom 3:23); salvation restores the glory-relationship. Christ is 'the radiance of God's glory' (Heb 1:3) - seeing Him, we see the Father's glory. The Spirit transforms believers into Christ's glorious image (2 Cor 3:18). Eschatology culminates in glory: 'When Christ who is your life appears, you also will appear with Him in glory' (Col 3:4). Worship is giving God the glory due His name - the δόξα that acknowledges His infinite worth.

entries.shortDef: law, principle, norm, the Mosaic Law
entries.title: Law: Torah, Principle, and the Pedagogue to Christ
entries.summary: Νόμος is the NT word for law - especially the Mosaic Law (Torah), but also law as principle or norm. Paul's treatment of νόμος is central to understanding justification: the law reveals sin, condemns sinners, but cannot save. Christ is the end (τέλος) of the law for righteousness.
entries.classicalGreek: In classical Greek, νόμος meant custom, usage, or law - that which is assigned or apportioned as normal. It could refer to musical modes, civic laws, or social conventions. The emphasis was on established practice recognized as binding. Νόμος stood for order against chaos, civilization against barbarism.
entries.lxxBackground: The LXX uses νόμος primarily for תּוֹרָה (torah) - instruction, teaching, law. Torah is more than legislation; it is God's instruction for covenant life. The Pentateuch is 'the Law.' The Psalms celebrate the law: 'Oh how I love your law!' (Ps 119:97). The law is God's gracious gift revealing His will. Yet the prophets anticipate a new covenant with law written on hearts (Jer 31:33).
entries.intertestamental: Second Temple Judaism intensified focus on Torah observance. The 'fence around the law' (oral traditions) developed. The Pharisees sought precise Torah keeping. The Qumran community had their own strict legal interpretations. Keeping the law was seen as the path to righteousness and national restoration. Different groups debated what proper law-keeping looked like.
entries.ntUsage: Paul's letters wrestle extensively with νόμος. The law is 'holy, righteous, and good' (Rom 7:12), yet 'by works of the law no one will be justified' (Gal 2:16). The law reveals sin (Rom 3:20; 7:7), increases transgression (Rom 5:20), and brings curse (Gal 3:10). Yet the law was a 'pedagogue' leading to Christ (Gal 3:24). Christ is 'the end of the law for righteousness' (Rom 10:4). Believers are 'not under law but under grace' (Rom 6:14), yet fulfill 'the law of Christ' (Gal 6:2) and 'the law of the Spirit of life' (Rom 8:2). James speaks of 'the perfect law of liberty' (Jas 1:25; 2:12). Jesus came not to abolish but to fulfill the law (Matt 5:17).

keyPassages.greek: ἐξ ἔργων νόμου οὐ δικαιωθήσεται πᾶσα σὰρξ ἐνώπιον αὐτοῦ, διὰ γὰρ νόμου ἐπίγνωσις ἁμαρτίας
keyPassages.significance: By works of law no flesh justified; through law comes knowledge of sin - the law diagnoses but cannot cure.

keyPassages.greek: ὁ νόμος παιδαγωγὸς ἡμῶν γέγονεν εἰς Χριστόν
keyPassages.significance: The law was our pedagogue unto Christ - its purpose was to lead us to the Savior.

keyPassages.greek: τέλος γὰρ νόμου Χριστὸς εἰς δικαιοσύνην παντὶ τῷ πιστεύοντι
keyPassages.significance: Christ is the end/goal of the law for righteousness to everyone who believes.

entries.theologicalSignificance: Understanding νόμος is essential for grasping Paul's gospel. The law is God's good gift revealing His holy will. Yet the law cannot justify because sinful humans cannot keep it perfectly (Rom 8:3). The law's purpose was never to save but to expose sin and drive sinners to Christ. Those in Christ are free from the law's condemnation (Rom 8:1) yet fulfill the law's intent through love (Rom 13:8-10). The Reformation's 'three uses of the law' (to restrain evil, reveal sin, guide believers) capture the NT's nuanced treatment. Christ fulfills the law's demands and frees believers from its curse.

relatedWords.relationship: Pertaining to law; lawyer, legal expert (Luke 7:30; Titus 3:9)

entries.title: The Cross: Scandal, Power, and Glory
entries.summary: Σταυρός is the cross - the instrument of Jesus' execution that became Christianity's central symbol. To the ancient world, crucifixion was shameful torture reserved for slaves and criminals. Paul proclaims this scandal as 'the power of God' - God's wisdom hidden in apparent foolishness.
entries.classicalGreek: In classical Greek, σταυρός meant an upright stake or pole, often used for impaling or hanging. By Roman times, it designated the cross-shaped instrument of execution. Crucifixion was the most shameful death imaginable - reserved for slaves, rebels, and the worst criminals. Cicero called it 'the most cruel and disgusting penalty.' The word carried connotations of utter degradation and curse.
entries.lxxBackground: The LXX does not use σταυρός, but Deuteronomy 21:22-23 declares that one 'hung on a tree' is under God's curse. This passage becomes crucial for NT interpretation: Christ became a curse for us by hanging on a tree (Gal 3:13). The OT also foreshadows: the bronze serpent lifted up (Num 21:8-9; John 3:14), the Passover lamb's blood (Ex 12), the Suffering Servant (Isa 53).
entries.intertestamental: Crucifixion was used by Greeks and Romans throughout this period. The Qumran pesher on Nahum mentions 'hanging alive on a tree.' Jewish sources viewed crucifixion as cursed death. The cross was associated with shame, torture, and divine rejection. No one could have anticipated that the Messiah would be crucified.
entries.ntUsage: The Gospels narrate Jesus' crucifixion in detail (Matt 27; Mark 15; Luke 23; John 19). Jesus calls disciples to 'take up the cross' (Matt 16:24) - accepting shame and death for His sake. Paul makes the cross central: 'I decided to know nothing among you except Jesus Christ and Him crucified' (1 Cor 2:2). The cross is foolishness to Greeks and scandal to Jews, but to believers 'the power of God' (1 Cor 1:18, 23-24). Through the cross, God reconciles all things (Col 1:20), breaks down dividing walls (Eph 2:16), cancels the debt against us (Col 2:14), and defeats powers (Col 2:15). Believers are 'crucified with Christ' (Gal 2:20) and crucify the flesh (Gal 5:24). The cross is both historical event and ongoing reality.

keyPassages.greek: ὁ λόγος γὰρ ὁ τοῦ σταυροῦ τοῖς μὲν ἀπολλυμένοις μωρία ἐστίν, τοῖς δὲ σῳζομένοις ἡμῖν δύναμις θεοῦ ἐστιν
keyPassages.significance: The word of the cross is foolishness to the perishing but the power of God to the saved.

keyPassages.greek: ἐμοὶ δὲ μὴ γένοιτο καυχᾶσθαι εἰ μὴ ἐν τῷ σταυρῷ τοῦ κυρίου ἡμῶν Ἰησοῦ Χριστοῦ
keyPassages.significance: Far be it from me to boast except in the cross of our Lord Jesus Christ.

keyPassages.greek: ἐξαλείψας τὸ καθ᾽ ἡμῶν χειρόγραφον... προσηλώσας αὐτὸ τῷ σταυρῷ
keyPassages.significance: Canceling the record of debt by nailing it to the cross - debt paid, powers defeated.

entries.theologicalSignificance: The σταυρός revolutionizes all human values. What the world sees as shameful defeat, God reveals as glorious victory. The cross is where God's wrath and mercy meet: Christ bears the curse we deserved (Gal 3:13), becoming sin for us (2 Cor 5:21). The cross is substitutionary atonement - the just dying for the unjust. It is also victory - through apparent defeat, Christ triumphed over sin, death, and demonic powers (Col 2:15). The cross shapes Christian life: believers are crucified with Christ (Gal 2:20), dying to sin and self. 'Taking up the cross' means accepting suffering, shame, and self-denial for Christ's sake. The cross remains 'folly' to the world but 'the power of God' to believers.

entries.title: Resurrection: The Defeat of Death
entries.summary: Ἀνάστασις means resurrection - rising from the dead. Christ's resurrection is Christianity's foundation: 'If Christ has not been raised, your faith is futile' (1 Cor 15:17). Believers share in Christ's resurrection now spiritually and will share bodily at His return. Resurrection is not mere resuscitation but transformation into glorious, immortal life.
entries.classicalGreek: In classical Greek, ἀνάστασις meant a rising up or standing - from seats, from sleep, or in general. It could refer to removal, migration, or recovery. The concept of bodily resurrection from death was largely foreign to Greek thought, which generally viewed death as the soul's liberation from the body. The body was a prison, not something to be raised.
entries.lxxBackground: The LXX uses ἀνάστασις occasionally, but the concept develops in later OT books. Daniel 12:2 is the clearest OT resurrection text: 'Many who sleep in the dust of the earth shall awake.' Isaiah 26:19 declares 'Your dead shall live; their bodies shall rise.' Ezekiel's valley of dry bones (Ezek 37) symbolizes national restoration but suggests bodily resurrection. The Maccabean martyrs died believing in resurrection (2 Macc 7).
entries.intertestamental: By Jesus' time, resurrection was debated. The Pharisees affirmed bodily resurrection; the Sadducees denied it (Acts 23:8). Apocalyptic texts (1 Enoch, 4 Ezra) developed resurrection hope. The Qumran community's beliefs are debated but may have included resurrection. Most Jews who believed in resurrection expected it at the end of history, not within it.
entries.ntUsage: Jesus affirms resurrection and claims to be 'the resurrection and the life' (John 11:25). He debates Sadducees, proving resurrection from Scripture (Matt 22:23-33). The apostolic preaching centers on Jesus' resurrection: 'God raised Him from the dead' (Acts 2:24, 32; 3:15; 4:10; 10:40; 13:30). Paul's gospel is that Christ 'was raised on the third day' (1 Cor 15:4). 1 Corinthians 15 is the fullest treatment: Christ's resurrection guarantees ours; the resurrection body is transformed, spiritual, glorious, imperishable. Believers already participate in Christ's resurrection (Rom 6:4-5; Eph 2:5-6; Col 3:1) and await bodily resurrection at His coming (1 Thess 4:16; Phil 3:21).

keyPassages.greek: εἰ δὲ Χριστὸς οὐκ ἐγήγερται, ματαία ἡ πίστις ὑμῶν
keyPassages.significance: If Christ has not been raised, your faith is futile - resurrection is non-negotiable.

keyPassages.greek: ἐγώ εἰμι ἡ ἀνάστασις καὶ ἡ ζωή
keyPassages.significance: I AM the resurrection and the life - Jesus embodies resurrection, not just teaches it.

keyPassages.greek: τοῦ γνῶναι αὐτὸν καὶ τὴν δύναμιν τῆς ἀναστάσεως αὐτοῦ
keyPassages.significance: To know Him and the power of His resurrection - resurrection power transforms present life.

entries.theologicalSignificance: Ἀνάστασις is Christianity's cornerstone. Without resurrection, there is no Christianity (1 Cor 15:14-19). Christ's resurrection vindicates His claims, demonstrates His deity, conquers death, and guarantees our resurrection. The resurrection is historical - it happened in space and time - yet also eschatological - it inaugurates the new creation. Believers already share in resurrection life spiritually (Eph 2:5-6) and will share bodily at Christ's return. The resurrection body is not resuscitated flesh but transformed, glorified, immortal (1 Cor 15:42-54). Resurrection affirms the body's goodness - God redeems, not abandons, His material creation. Easter is not an appendix to Good Friday but its vindication and completion.

relatedWords.relationship: To raise, wake (1 Cor 15:4, 12-20 - often used for resurrection)

entries.title: Repentance: The Turning That Transforms
entries.summary: Μετάνοια is repentance - a radical change of mind that produces changed behavior. More than regret or remorse, it is a fundamental reorientation of life toward God. John the Baptist, Jesus, and the apostles all preach: 'Repent!' It is the human response to God's grace, inseparable from faith.
entries.classicalGreek: In classical Greek, μετάνοια meant afterthought, change of mind, or regret. It could indicate reconsideration of a decision or remorse over past action. The emphasis was cognitive - changing one's thinking. It did not carry the strong moral and religious weight it gains in biblical usage.
entries.lxxBackground: The LXX uses μετανοέω occasionally, but more often uses ἐπιστρέφω (to turn) for Hebrew שׁוּב (shuv) - the primary OT term for repentance. Prophetic preaching calls Israel to 'return' to God (Jer 3:12; Hos 14:1; Joel 2:12-13). Repentance involves turning from sin and turning to God. It is both gift and demand, enabled by God yet commanded of humans (Ezek 18:30-32).
entries.intertestamental: Second Temple Judaism emphasized repentance as the path back to God. The Qumran community called for radical repentance and separation from sinners. Rabbinic literature extensively discussed repentance (teshuvah). Some texts speak of God's patience giving opportunity for repentance. John the Baptist's call to repentance (Matt 3:2) stood in this tradition yet announced something new - the kingdom was at hand.
entries.ntUsage: John the Baptist preaches 'Repent, for the kingdom of heaven is at hand' (Matt 3:2). Jesus begins His ministry with the same call (Matt 4:17; Mark 1:15). Repentance is essential for forgiveness (Luke 24:47; Acts 2:38; 3:19; 5:31). Paul preached 'repentance toward God and faith in our Lord Jesus Christ' (Acts 20:21). God's kindness leads to repentance (Rom 2:4). God grants repentance (Acts 11:18; 2 Tim 2:25) - it is His gift. Yet humans are commanded to repent (Acts 17:30). Repentance produces fruit (Matt 3:8; Acts 26:20) - changed behavior demonstrates genuine change of heart. There is joy in heaven over one sinner who repents (Luke 15:7, 10).

keyPassages.greek: μετανοεῖτε καὶ πιστεύετε ἐν τῷ εὐαγγελίῳ
keyPassages.significance: Repent and believe the gospel - repentance and faith are the twin responses to good news.

keyPassages.greek: μετανοήσατε καὶ βαπτισθήτω ἕκαστος ὑμῶν
keyPassages.significance: Repent and be baptized - Peter's Pentecost call, the apostolic gospel demand.

keyPassages.greek: ἡ γὰρ κατὰ θεὸν λύπη μετάνοιαν εἰς σωτηρίαν ἀμεταμέλητον ἐργάζεται
keyPassages.significance: Godly grief produces repentance leading to salvation - distinguishing true from worldly sorrow.

entries.theologicalSignificance: Μετάνοια is more than feeling sorry or even changing behavior - it is a fundamental reorientation of the whole person toward God. It involves mind (new understanding), emotions (godly sorrow), and will (changed direction). Repentance is inseparable from faith - two sides of one coin, as turning from sin is turning to Christ. Though commanded, repentance is ultimately God's gift (Acts 11:18) - only His grace enables genuine change. Repentance is not merely initial conversion but ongoing posture: believers continually turn from sin. The Reformation recovered repentance's centrality: Luther's first thesis declared 'the whole life of believers should be repentance.'

relatedWords.relationship: To repent, change one's mind (Matt 3:2; Acts 2:38)
To regret, feel remorse (Matt 27:3 - Judas's regret, not saving repentance)
To turn, convert (Acts 3:19; 26:18 - often paired with repent)

entries.title: The Coming: Christ's Return in Glory
entries.summary: Παρουσία means 'presence' or 'coming' - technically, the arrival that initiates presence. It became the technical term for Christ's second coming: His glorious return to judge the living and dead, raise believers, and consummate the kingdom. The παρουσία is the 'blessed hope' that shapes Christian living.
entries.classicalGreek: In classical Greek, παρουσία meant presence (as opposed to absence) or the act of arriving that establishes presence. It was used for the visit of a king or dignitary to a city - an 'advent' or royal visitation. Such visits were occasions for preparation, celebration, and benefaction. The term carried connotations of a significant, transformative arrival.
entries.lxxBackground: The LXX uses παρουσία occasionally for presence or arrival. The OT anticipates 'the Day of the LORD' (יוֹם יהוה) - God's coming to judge and save (Amos 5:18-20; Joel 2:1-11; Zeph 1:14-18; Mal 4:1-6). This 'coming' would be both terrifying (for God's enemies) and glorious (for His people). The prophetic hope of God's definitive intervention sets the stage for NT παρουσία theology.
entries.intertestamental: Apocalyptic texts developed the expectation of God's end-time intervention. The 'Son of Man' coming on clouds (Dan 7:13) influenced messianic expectation. Various texts anticipated the Messiah's coming to defeat evil and establish God's reign. The Qumran community awaited multiple messianic figures. The 'coming age' would replace 'this age.'
