entries.ntUsage: Jesus speaks of 'the coming of the Son of Man' (Matt 24:27, 37, 39) - sudden, visible, glorious. Paul frequently references Christ's παρουσία: believers will be raised 'at His coming' (1 Cor 15:23); the Lord will descend from heaven (1 Thess 4:15); believers should be blameless 'at the coming of our Lord Jesus Christ' (1 Thess 5:23). James urges patience 'until the Lord's coming' (Jas 5:7-8). Peter defends the παρουσία against scoffers (2 Pet 3:4, 12). John says believers should 'abide in Him, so that when He appears we may have confidence' (1 John 2:28). The παρουσία shapes ethics: live in light of His return.

keyPassages.greek: οὕτως ἔσται ἡ παρουσία τοῦ υἱοῦ τοῦ ἀνθρώπου
keyPassages.significance: So will be the coming of the Son of Man - sudden, unmistakable, like lightning.

keyPassages.greek: ἡμεῖς οἱ ζῶντες οἱ περιλειπόμενοι εἰς τὴν παρουσίαν τοῦ κυρίου
keyPassages.significance: We who are alive and remain until the Lord's coming - the παρουσία as believers' hope.

keyPassages.greek: προσδοκῶντας καὶ σπεύδοντας τὴν παρουσίαν τῆς τοῦ θεοῦ ἡμέρας
keyPassages.significance: Waiting for and hastening the coming of the day of God - active expectation.

entries.theologicalSignificance: The παρουσία is Christianity's 'blessed hope' (Titus 2:13). Christ who ascended will return 'in the same way' (Acts 1:11). His coming will be personal, visible, glorious, and decisive. It will bring resurrection of the dead (1 Cor 15:23; 1 Thess 4:16), transformation of the living (1 Cor 15:51-52), judgment of all (2 Thess 1:7-10; Matt 25:31-46), destruction of evil (2 Thess 2:8), and consummation of the kingdom. The παρουσία creates urgency: 'the Lord is at hand' (Phil 4:5). It shapes ethics: live worthily of His return (1 Thess 5:1-11). It provides comfort: reunion with deceased believers (1 Thess 4:13-18). Against scoffers, Peter insists the delay is God's patience (2 Pet 3:9). Maranatha - 'Our Lord, come!' (1 Cor 16:22).

relatedWords.relationship: To come - Jesus promises 'I am coming' (John 14:3; Rev 22:20)
Revelation, appearing - Christ's 'revelation' at His coming (1 Cor 1:7; 1 Pet 1:7)
Appearing, manifestation - used for Christ's return (2 Tim 4:8; Titus 2:13)

entries.shortDef: mystery, secret, hidden truth now revealed
entries.title: Mystery: The Open Secret of God's Plan
entries.summary: Μυστήριον in the NT is not something mysterious or unknowable, but a secret now revealed - God's hidden plan disclosed in Christ. The 'mystery' was kept secret for ages but is now made known: Gentiles are fellow heirs with Jews in Christ. God's wisdom, hidden from rulers, is revealed to believers through the Spirit.
entries.classicalGreek: In classical Greek, μυστήριον referred to the secret rites of mystery religions (Eleusinian, Dionysian, etc.) - sacred knowledge revealed only to initiates. These 'mysteries' were kept secret from outsiders. The term carried connotations of hidden wisdom, sacred initiation, and esoteric knowledge unavailable to the uninitiated.
entries.lxxBackground: The LXX uses μυστήριον primarily in Daniel for רָז (raz) - secret, mystery. Daniel reveals Nebuchadnezzar's dream because 'there is a God in heaven who reveals mysteries' (Dan 2:28-29, 47). God discloses what is hidden. The apocalyptic tradition developed this: heavenly secrets are revealed to chosen seers. Unlike pagan mysteries kept permanently secret, divine mysteries are revealed.
entries.intertestamental: Apocalyptic literature extensively uses mystery language. Heavenly secrets about the end times, cosmic battles, and divine plans are 'revealed' to visionaries (1 Enoch, 4 Ezra). The Qumran community believed they received special revelation of Scripture's mysteries. The 'mystery' is God's hidden plan, now disclosed to the elect.
entries.ntUsage: Paul uses μυστήριον most frequently. The 'mystery of Christ' was hidden for ages but now revealed: Gentiles are fellow heirs (Eph 3:3-6). The 'mystery of the gospel' (Eph 6:19) is this inclusive salvation. Colossians declares 'Christ in you, the hope of glory' is the mystery (Col 1:27; 2:2). Romans concludes with the mystery 'kept secret for long ages but now disclosed' (Rom 16:25-26). 1 Corinthians 2:7 speaks of 'God's wisdom, secret and hidden, which God decreed before the ages.' The 'mystery of lawlessness' is already at work (2 Thess 2:7). Revelation speaks of 'the mystery of God' being fulfilled (Rev 10:7). Marriage reflects 'the mystery' of Christ and the church (Eph 5:32).

keyPassages.greek: τὸ μυστήριον τοῦ Χριστοῦ... εἶναι τὰ ἔθνη συγκληρονόμα
keyPassages.significance: The mystery of Christ: Gentiles are fellow heirs - the previously hidden inclusion now revealed.

keyPassages.greek: τὸ μυστήριον τὸ ἀποκεκρυμμένον... νῦν δὲ ἐφανερώθη... ὅ ἐστιν Χριστὸς ἐν ὑμῖν
keyPassages.significance: The mystery hidden for ages now revealed: Christ in you, the hope of glory.

keyPassages.greek: θεοῦ σοφίαν ἐν μυστηρίῳ τὴν ἀποκεκρυμμένην
keyPassages.significance: God's wisdom in a mystery, hidden - now revealed through the Spirit.

entries.theologicalSignificance: NT μυστήριον is not unknowable but now-known - the 'open secret.' God's eternal plan, hidden from human wisdom and even angelic powers, is revealed in Christ. The central mystery is the inclusion of Gentiles: through Christ, the dividing wall is broken and all peoples become one body (Eph 2-3). This mystery is not discovered by human investigation but revealed by divine disclosure. It is known through the Spirit (1 Cor 2:10) and proclaimed by apostles (Eph 3:8-9). The mystery reveals God's wisdom - what seemed foolish (a crucified Messiah) is actually the deepest wisdom. Believers are 'stewards of God's mysteries' (1 Cor 4:1), entrusted with revealed truth to proclaim.

relatedWords.relationship: To reveal, uncover - mysteries are 'revealed' (Rom 16:25; Eph 3:5)
To manifest, make known - the mystery is 'made manifest' (Col 1:26)
To hide - the mystery was 'hidden' for ages (Eph 3:9; Col 1:26)
